subtitle: 12 minutes of selected historical points from his life.
name: Martin Luther King Jr.
title: Martin Luther King Jr.
preb: [{"tags": "", "text": "Martin Luther (originally Michael) King Jr. is born in Atlanta, Georgia, the middle child of 3 children. His father is a minister active in civil rights, and his mother is a musician and teacher.  Growing up with racism in the segregated South, King struggles with depression, but is an outstanding student and becomes known for his public speaking ability.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5764144745676800", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1929-01-15", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-14T19:02:49Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5764144745676800", "modified": "2019-01-11T06:25:24Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk01"},{"tags": "", "text": "On return from the World Baptist Alliance in Berlin, Michael King Sr. changes his name (and that of his son) to Martin Luther, in honor and reflection of the 16th century reformer.", "refs": "[\"Carson, Clayborne; Luker, Ralph E.; Russell, Penny A.; Harlan, Louis R., eds. The Papers of Martin Luther King, Jr., Volume I: Called to Serve, January 1929\u2013June 1951. University of California Press. p. 30-31. ISBN 0-520-07950-7.\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1934", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-14T19:05:47Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5743661174226944", "modified": "2018-12-14T19:14:44Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk02"},{"tags": "", "text": "At 15 years old, Martin Luther King Jr. enters Morehouse College as an early admission student.  He graduates in 1948 with a B.A. in Sociology, having decided the summer before his senior year that he wants to become a minister.", "refs": "[\"http://www.morehouse.edu/kingcollection/life.php\"]", "pic": "5705311142805504", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1944", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-14T19:10:46Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5705311142805504", "modified": "2018-12-14T19:10:46Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk03"},{"tags": "", "text": "King enrolls in Crozer Theological Seminary, graduating with a Bachelor of Divinity in 1951.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5705848751915008", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1948", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-14T19:25:14Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5705848751915008", "modified": "2018-12-14T19:25:14Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk04"},{"tags": "", "text": "King enrolls at Boston University, graduating with a Doctorate of Philosophy in Systematic Theology in 1955.  In his notes and in his dissertation, King includes text from other sources without attribution.  Boston University reviews the plagiarism in 1991 and decides his doctorate should not be revoked.", "refs": "[\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/dissertation-martin-luther-king-jr\",\"Carson et al., \u201cMartin Luther King, Jr., as Scholar: A Reexamination of His Theological Writings,\u201d Journal of American History 78 (June 1991): 93\u2013105.\",\"Keith D. Miller\",\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/opinions/1990/11/18/how-king-borrowed/d6fcf0f9-60a1-4b6a-86aa-137075f401e9/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.5206251add21\"]", "pic": "5658091668373504", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1951", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-14T22:48:34Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5658091668373504", "modified": "2018-12-14T22:48:34Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk05"},{"tags": "", "text": "King marries Coretta Scott, a talented musician and political activist from Alabama studying at the New England Conservatory.  She requests \"obey\" be omitted from their marriage vows, while letting go of her music career.  She remains active politically with Martin while raising their 4 children.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coretta_Scott_King\",\"https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2018/02/coretta-scott-king/552557/\",\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/03/coretta-scott-king-extract\"]", "pic": "5741642204053504", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1953-06-18", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-14T22:52:41Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5741642204053504", "modified": "2018-12-14T22:52:41Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk06"},{"tags": "", "text": "Claudette Colvin, a 15 year old black schoolgirl, refuses to give up her bus seat to a white man and is arrested.  King is on the community committee led by E.D. Nixon that is seeking to challenge the discriminatory bus laws.  The decision is made to wait for a more suitable case.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claudette_Colvin\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._D._Nixon\"]", "pic": "5644478098440192", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1955-03-02", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-18T00:30:34Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5644478098440192", "modified": "2018-12-18T00:32:50Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk07"},{"tags": "", "text": "Rosa Parks, secretary of the Montgomery chapter of the NAACP, is arrested for refusing to give up her seat in the \"colored section\" of the bus to a white passenger.  Organizing begins for a bus boycott to start the following Monday.  King is elected president of the Montgomery Improvement Association formed to oversee the boycott.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosa_Parks\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montgomery_Improvement_Association\"]", "pic": "5747976207073280", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1955-12-01", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-18T00:32:22Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5747976207073280", "modified": "2018-12-18T00:37:23Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk08"},{"tags": "", "text": "King's house is firebombed, as part of widespread violence against boycotters and black Baptist churches.  King urges nonviolence.  Boycott leaders and carpool drivers are indicted and jailed.  Hoover's FBI begins targeting King.  The boycott continues.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coretta_Scott_King#House_bombing\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montgomery_bus_boycott\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5204840548401152", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1956-01-30", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-18T00:35:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5204840548401152", "modified": "2018-12-18T00:47:09Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk09"},{"tags": "", "text": "In Browder v. Gayle, a federal district court rules that Alabama's racial segregation laws for buses are unconstitutional.  The state appeals the ruling, which is then upheld by the U.S. Supreme court.  The boycott ends on Dec 20, after the city finally passes an ordinance authorizing black passengers to sit where they choose.  Despite violent white backlash, the civil-rights victory is won and King becomes known nationally.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montgomery_bus_boycott\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5710311357153280", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1956-06-04", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-18T00:40:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5710311357153280", "modified": "2018-12-18T00:44:21Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk10"},{"tags": "", "text": "King and other civil rights activists found the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) to coordinate and support nonviolent direct action.  The goal of the group is to end all forms of segregation.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Christian_Leadership_Conference\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5635093192245248", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1957-01-10", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-18T01:19:14Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5635093192245248", "modified": "2018-12-18T01:19:14Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk11"},{"tags": "", "text": "King signs a contract with Harper & Brothers to write his account of Montgomery before, during, and after the bus boycott. \"Stride Toward Freedom: The Montgomery Story\" is released in 1958.  Chapter 6 \"Pilgrimate to Nonviolence\" describes King's philosophy of active nonviolent resistance.", "refs": "[\"http://nationalhumanitiescenter.org/ows/seminars/aahistory/Pilgrimage.pdf\",\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/stride-toward-freedom-montgomery-story\"]", "pic": "5664869730746368", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1957-10", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-18T21:31:58Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5664869730746368", "modified": "2018-12-18T21:31:58Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk12"},{"tags": "", "text": "A fundraising ad for the legal defense of King, support for student activists, and the struggle for the right to vote is placed in the New York Times.  Montgomery Public Safety commissioner L. B. Sullivan sues for defamation, despite not even being named in the ad.  He wins $500k in Alabama court and the verdict is appealed all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court which rules that news publications cannot be sued for libel unless actual malice is established in the false reporting of a news story.", "refs": "[\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e3/Heed_Their_Rising_Voices.jpg\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Times_Co._v._Sullivan\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1960-03-29", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-18T23:16:24Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5101919777325056", "modified": "2018-12-21T23:00:48Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk13"},{"tags": "", "text": "King becomes the only person ever prosecuted under the Alabama income tax perjury statute.  A jury of 12 white men finds him not guilty.", "refs": "[\"https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1G1-108788089/a-triumph-of-justice-in-alabama-the-1960-perjury\",\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/kellyphillipserb/2014/01/20/why-justice-matters-the-indictment-trial-of-dr-martin-luther-king-on-tax-charges\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1960-05", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-18T23:18:55Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5735267667279872", "modified": "2018-12-18T23:19:44Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk14"},{"tags": "", "text": "King visits segregation protests in Albany, Georgia and is caught up in a mass arrest.  Intensive general desegregation actions by the Albany Movement continue for nearly a year but are eventually unsustainable.  King decides future protests should focus on single, distinct facets of segregation.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albany_Movement\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1961-12-14", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-21T22:57:52Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5654456649646080", "modified": "2018-12-21T22:57:52Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk15"},{"tags": "", "text": "SCLC desegregation activists begin occupying public spaces in Birmingham AL, eventually including children and young adults.  Police use dogs and water cannon against them, and police brutality is broadcast on national news.  King is arrested, and while in jail writes his response to newspaper article by white Alabama clergymen.  The campaign is successful, and King's \"Letter from Birmingham Jail\" becomes highly quoted.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birmingham_campaign\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letter_from_Birmingham_Jail\"]", "pic": "5090345041788928", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1963-04", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-23T17:54:31Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5090345041788928", "modified": "2019-01-08T22:19:59Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk16"},{"tags": "", "text": "President Johnson signs the Civil Rights Act. The most sweeping civil rights legislation since Reconstruction, the Civil Rights Act prohibits discrimination of all kinds based on race, color, religion, or national origin. The law also provides the federal government with the powers to enforce desegregation.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American,Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa", "date": "1964-07-02", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:17Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5618671653224448", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:17Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B158"},{"tags": "", "text": "King and the SCLC answer a request for assistance from Dr. Robert Hayling and join desegregation activists in St. Augustine, Florida.  Protesters face intimidation and violent attacks.  Jails overflow, with people kept in uncovered open air stockades.  The arrested include a large group of rabbis and the 72 year old mother of the governor of Massachusetts, bringing international attention to the campaign.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Augustine_movement\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Hayling\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5725637813731328", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1964-03", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-24T17:20:00Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5725637813731328", "modified": "2018-12-24T17:20:00Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk17"},{"tags": "", "text": "The FBI Counter Intelligence Program (COINTELPRO) marks King as the \"the most dangerous Negro of the future in this nation\".  Incidental details learned from phone wiretapping and bugged hotel rooms are used in attempts to force King out of his leadership position.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COINTELPRO\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\",\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/mlks-speech-attracted-fbis-intense-attention/2013/08/27/31c8ebd4-0f60-11e3-8cdd-bcdc09410972_story.html\",\"Weiner, Tim (2012). Enemies: A History of the FBI\"]", "pic": "5671907638640640", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1963-08-30", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-24T20:26:40Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5671907638640640", "modified": "2018-12-24T20:26:40Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk18"},{"tags": "", "text": "King delivers his \"I have a dream\" speech at the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.  The SCLC is one of several organizations involved with the march planned and organized by A. Philip Randolph and Bayard Rustin.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/March_on_Washington_for_Jobs_and_Freedom\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5701751084679168", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1963-08-28", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-12-25T22:22:27Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5701751084679168", "modified": "2019-01-08T23:08:59Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk19"},{"tags": "", "text": "Congress passes the Voting Rights Act, making it easier for Southern Blacks to vote. Literacy tests, poll taxes, and other such requirements that were used to restrict Black voting are made illegal. In addition, jurisdictions containing significant language minority populations are required to provide bilingual ballots and other election materials.", "refs": "[]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American,Latino/as,Asian American", "date": "1965-08-06", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5626543522971648", "modified": "2019-01-11T01:31:57Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B165"},{"tags": "", "text": "King is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for civil rights and social justice.  He announces he will turn over the prize money to the furtherance of the civil rights movement.", "refs": "[\"https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/peace/1964/king/biographical/\",\"https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/peace/1964/king/acceptance-speech/\"]", "pic": "5737740897353728", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1964-10-14", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-02T02:51:50Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5737740897353728", "modified": "2019-01-02T02:51:50Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk20"},{"tags": "", "text": "Answering a request for assistance from Frederick Douglas Reese and other local activists, King defies a Selma Alabama court injunction forbidding civil rights meetings to start a new wave of voter registration and protest organizing.  By the first week of February, over 3000 are arrested, including King.  Police block black teachers trying to register to vote and push them down the courthouse stairs jabbing them with billy clubs.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_D._Reese\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selma_to_Montgomery_marches\",\"The Selma Voting Rights Struggle & March to Montgomery, Bruce Hartford, 2014\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5691420614590464", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-01-02", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-05T03:21:21Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5691420614590464", "modified": "2019-01-05T03:21:21Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk21"},{"tags": "", "text": "President Johnson returns King's phone call to discuss strategy for ending abusive voter literacy requirements and other political issues such as diversifying the cabinet. [pic: King and Johnson meeting the next year]", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selma_to_Montgomery_marches\",\"https://millercenter.org/the-presidency/secret-white-house-tapes/conversation-martin-luther-king-and-office-secretary\"]", "pic": "5738275486564352", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-01-15", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-05T03:55:11Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5738275486564352", "modified": "2019-01-08T22:44:42Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk22"},{"tags": "", "text": "Deacon Jimmy Lee Jackson dies from infection after having been shot by a state trooper the week before.  SCLC director James Bevel calls for a long march from Selma to Montgomery in order to channel community outrage into nonviolent action.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murder_of_Jimmie_Lee_Jackson\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selma_to_Montgomery_marches\"]", "pic": "5651757665353728", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-02-26", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-05T03:58:41Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5651757665353728", "modified": "2019-01-05T03:58:41Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk23"},{"tags": "", "text": "Bloody Sunday: Unarmed marchers are attacked by state troopers and mounted possemen when they cross the Edmund Pettus Bridge county line.  The police shoot teargas, protesters are beaten with billy clubs and trampled by horsemen.  Amelia Boynton is beaten unconscious.  50 marchers are injured, 17 are hospitalized.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selma_to_Montgomery_marches\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amelia_Boynton_Robinson\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5724948068827136", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-03-07", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-05T04:06:11Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5724948068827136", "modified": "2019-01-05T04:06:11Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk24"},{"tags": "", "text": "Turnaround Tuesday: Rather than violate a federal restraining order, King turns the second march around at the county line bridge.  That night, three white unitarian ministers are attacked and beaten with clubs by the KKK.  One of them, James Reeb, dies two days later.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selma_to_Montgomery_marches\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Reeb\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5741754678509568", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-03-09", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-05T06:55:18Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5741754678509568", "modified": "2019-01-05T06:55:18Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk25"},{"tags": "", "text": "Johnson holds a nationally televised joint session of Congress asking for introduction and passage of the voting rights bill.  Over the next days, Johnson gives his enforcement commitment for the march, the restraining order is lifted, the Alabama National Guard is federalized for escort, and the march begins.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selma_to_Montgomery_marches\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-03-15", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-05T07:52:26Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5648334039547904", "modified": "2019-01-05T07:52:26Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk26"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Selma to Montgomery march reaches the state capital.  King delivers his \"How Long, Not Long\" speech.  That night Viola Liuzzo, a white supporter ferrying marchers back to Selma is shot by Klansmen.  In the car with the Klansmen is FBI informant Gary Rowe.  COINTELPRO begins a smear campaign against Liuzzo.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selma_to_Montgomery_marches\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viola_Liuzzo\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5740379684995072", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-03-25", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-05T08:10:49Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5740379684995072", "modified": "2019-01-08T23:09:24Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk27"},{"tags": "", "text": "King sends SCLC volunteers to assist the Coordinating Council of Community Organizations (CCCO), a loose coalition of numerous community and civil rights groups in Chicago.  The goal is to apply nonviolent resistance to racism in the North.", "refs": "[\"https://www.crmvet.org/tim/tim66b.htm\",\"https://www.chicagoreporter.com/the-roots-of-the-chicago-freedom-movement/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Freedom_Movement\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-09", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-08T19:51:28Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5697982787747840", "modified": "2019-01-08T19:51:28Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk28"},{"tags": "", "text": "King and the SCLC announce plans for the Chicago Freedom Movement, to \"help eradicate a vicious system which seeks to further colonize thousands of Negroes within a slum environment\".  King and his family move into 1550 S. Hamlin Avenue, a tenement apartment on the West Side.", "refs": "[\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/chicago-campaign\",\"https://www.crmvet.org/tim/tim66b.htm\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Freedom_Movement\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5654831519760384", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1966-01-07", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-08T19:53:08Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5654831519760384", "modified": "2019-01-08T19:53:08Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk29"},{"tags": "", "text": "The \"Freedom Festival\" starring multiple celebrity acts helps to replenish finances drained from grass roots organizing and nonviolent direct action.  In the North, the SCLC is unable to mobilize large scale support through church communities, and as King states: \"Slums with hundreds of thousands of living units are not eradicated as easily as lunch counters or buses are integrated.\"", "refs": "[\"https://www.crmvet.org/tim/tim66b.htm\",\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/chicago-campaign\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Freedom_Movement\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5704393160654848", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1966-03-12", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-08T20:09:28Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5704393160654848", "modified": "2019-01-08T20:09:28Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk30"},{"tags": "", "text": "A large rally at Soldier Field draws tens of thousands, but is smaller than hoped due to an oppressive heatwave.  The march is ignored by City Hall.  At a previously arranged meeting on Monday, Mayor Daley refuses to specifically address any demands.  Later, fire hydrants used by ghetto residents to cool off are locked down.  Legal orders to block discrimination by real estate agents are blocked.  Rioting is met by heavily armed police and National Guard soldiers.", "refs": "[\"https://www.crmvet.org/tim/tim66b.htm\",\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/chicago-campaign\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Freedom_Movement\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5647110175195136", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1966-07-10", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-08T20:12:26Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5647110175195136", "modified": "2019-01-08T20:12:26Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk31"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Chicago Freedom Movement issues an \"Open City Action Report\" calling for protests in all-white communities.  Protesters are met with violent opposition and minimal police protection.  King tells the press \"I had expected some hostility, but not of this enormity. I have never in my life seen such hate. Not in Mississippi or Alabama.\"", "refs": "[\"https://www.crmvet.org/tim/tim66b.htm\",\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/chicago-campaign\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Freedom_Movement\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1966-07-27", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-08T20:14:19Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5665497936822272", "modified": "2019-01-08T22:21:03Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk32"},{"tags": "", "text": "After more marches through violent opposition, and more meetings, a limited compromise agreement is finally signed, then ignored by the city.  The Gautreaux v. Chicago Housing Authority lawsuit against segregated housing is filed, and then fiercely fought all the way to the Supreme Court.  Opposition is divided, and Daley is re-elected.", "refs": "[\"https://www.crmvet.org/tim/tim66b.htm\",\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/chicago-campaign\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Freedom_Movement\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5689922476310528", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1966-08-25", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-08T20:16:29Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5689922476310528", "modified": "2019-01-08T20:16:29Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk33"},{"tags": "", "text": "King rents a secluded house with no telephone in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, and writes \"Where Do We Go from Here: Chaos or Community?\".  The book is published in June.  Among other themes, the book describes abolishing poverty through a guaranteed income, which King notes in a later speech would cost less than the unjust war in Vietnam.", "refs": "[\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/where-do-we-go-here-chaos-or-community\",\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/where-do-we-go-here\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Where_Do_We_Go_from_Here:_Chaos_or_Community%3F\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1967-01", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-08T23:12:51Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5684961520648192", "modified": "2019-01-08T23:12:51Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk34"},{"tags": "", "text": "King delivers his \"Beyond Vietnam: A Time to Break Silence\" speech at Riverside Church in NYC.  King continues to voice his opposition to the war, despite loss of of political allies, because \"my conscience leaves me no other choice\". \"A nation that continues year after year to spend more money on military defense than on programs of social uplift is approaching spiritual doom\".", "refs": "[\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/beyond-vietnam\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5712829080403968", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1967-04-04", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-10T08:05:18Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5712829080403968", "modified": "2019-01-10T08:05:18Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk35"},{"tags": "", "text": "King announces the Poor People's Campaign, extending across racial boundaries and continuing the theme of an Economic Bill of Rights introduced by FDR.  \"This will be no mere one-day march in Washington, but a trek to the nation's capital by suffering and outraged citizens who will go to stay until some definite and positive action is taken to provide jobs and income for the poor.\"", "refs": "[\"https://www.crmvet.org/docs/6712_mlk_ppc-anc.pdf\",\"https://www.crmvet.org/docs/68ebr.htm\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poor_People%27s_Campaign\"]", "pic": "5764640680181760", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1967-12-04", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-10T08:06:29Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5764640680181760", "modified": "2019-01-10T08:06:29Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk36"},{"tags": "", "text": "King is assassinated as he stands on the second floor balcony of the hotel he normally stayed at.  King had gone to Memphis to support black sanitary public works employees who were on strike.  At a Mason Temple rally the day before King said: \"Well, I don't know what will happen now. We've got some difficult days ahead. But it doesn't matter with me now. Because I've been to the mountaintop. And I don't mind. Like anybody, I would like to live a long life. Longevity has its place. But I'm not concerned about that now. I just want to do God's will. And He's allowed me to go up to the mountain. And I've looked over. And I've seen the promised land. I may not get there with you. But I want you to know tonight, that we, as a people, will get to the promised land. So I'm happy, tonight. I'm not worried about anything. I'm not fearing any man. Mine eyes have seen the glory of the coming of the Lord.\"", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5728885882748928", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1968-04-04", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-10T08:34:33Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5728885882748928", "modified": "2019-01-10T08:34:33Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk37"},{"tags": "", "text": "King's assasination triggers large scale civil disturbances across over 100 cities in the United States.  Large scale rioting in cities like New York, Indianapolis, and Boston, is averted through official acknowledgement of the tragedy.  Other cities, like Washington D.C., Chicago, and Baltimore are hit hard.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_assassination_riots\",\"https://www.history.com/news/mlk-assassination-riots-occupation\"]", "pic": "5631943370604544", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1968-04-05", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-11T01:26:12Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5631943370604544", "modified": "2019-01-11T01:26:12Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk38"},{"tags": "", "text": "King is posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom.  During his life King was awarded the Spingarn Medal from the NAACP, the American Liberties Medallion by the American Jewish Committee, the Margaret Sanger Award from the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, and the Nobel Peace Prize.  He was elected a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and earned at least fifty honorary degrees from colleges and universities.  During his life he received book awards, posthumously he was awarded a Grammy for spoken word.  He and Coretta were awarded the Congressional Gold Medal in 2004.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5755034180517888", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1977", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-11T01:27:08Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5755034180517888", "modified": "2019-01-11T01:27:08Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk39"},{"tags": "", "text": "Ronald Reagan signs a bill creating a federal holiday to honor King, nationalizing city and state holidays first begun in 1971.  Martin Luther King Jr. Day was first observed January 20, 1986 and since 1992 is observed on third Monday of January each year.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.\"]", "pic": "5684609735983104", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1983-11-02", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-01-11T01:28:17Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5684609735983104", "modified": "2019-01-11T01:28:17Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "mlk40"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Civil Rights Act (aka the Fair Housing Act) provides sweeping housing, voting, education and other protections and enforcement capabilies together with anti-riot measures.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American,Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa,Multiracial", "date": "1968-04-11", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:30Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6697698971353088", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:30Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B177"}]

subtitle: 10 minutes of selected historical points from her life.
name: Harriet Tubman
title: Harriet Tubman
preb: [{"tags": "", "text": "Araminta \"Minty\" Ross (later known as Harriet Tubman) is born into slavery as the fifth of 9 children on a plantation near the Blackwater River in Dorchester County, Maryland.  Her mother, Harriet \"Rit\" Green, is enslaved as a cook and her father, Ben Ross, is enslaved as a skilled woodsman.", "refs": "[\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero"\",\"http://www.harriettubmanbiography.com/harriet-tubman-biography.html\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\"]", "pic": "5665054615666688", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1822", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-07T20:45:01Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5665054615666688", "modified": "2019-03-19T20:08:11Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht01"},{"tags": "", "text": "Starting around five years old, Araminta is hired out to other masters.  She works first as a nursemaid, where she is whipped whenever the baby wakes up and cries.  Months later, she is returned severely debilitated, weak, and undernourished.  Her mother nurses her back to health, and she is hired out again.  This pattern repeats for her childhood.  Separated from her family, Araminta learns to resist when she can.", "refs": "[\"Catherine Clinton "Harriet Tubman: The Road to Freedom"\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero"\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\"]", "pic": "5703593692758016", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1828", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-08T14:44:54Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5703593692758016", "modified": "2019-02-15T21:42:08Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht02"},{"tags": "", "text": "Araminta is hired out to break flax.  While accompanying the house cook to purchase supplies at a nearby store, she is ordered by an overseer to help tie down a slave who had left work without permission.  Araminta refuses, the slave breaks free, the overseer picks up a weight and throws it at the escaping slave hitting Araminta above her left temple instead.  Araminta's skull is broken in.  For the rest of her life she suffers frequent and exhausting losses of consciousness lasting several minutes.  She also experiences vivid visions.", "refs": "[\"Kate Clifford Larson \\\"Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero\\\" pg42\",\"Catherine Clinton \\\"Harriet Tubman: The Road to Freedom\\\" pg22\",\"https://bucktownstore.com/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\"]", "pic": "5707967177424896", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1834", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-08T16:27:30Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5707967177424896", "modified": "2019-02-12T15:58:27Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht03"},{"tags": "", "text": "Araminta is hired out for timber work to John Stewart, who also employs her father.  Despite her disability, Araminta develops remarkable physical stamina and is able to haul more wood than many men (about a half cord a day).  Her Christian faith, first learned from her mother's Bible stories, also grows stronger.  Her work enables her to have contact with watermen, who have knowledge of regions beyond the plantation.", "refs": "[\"Kate Clifford Larson \\\"Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero\\\" pg63\",\"Catherine Clinton \\\"Harriet Tubman: The Road to Freedom\\\" pg23\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\"]", "pic": "5633267831144448", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1836", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-12T19:38:41Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5633267831144448", "modified": "2019-02-12T19:38:41Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht04"},{"tags": "", "text": "Araminta's father Ben Ross is manumitted, as stipulated in his master's will.  Araminta pays a lawyer to discover that her mother was also meant to be freed, but it would not be possible to win a legal challenge.  Around this time, Araminta had negotiated with her master to be able to hire herself out, in exchange for paying him $50-$60/year.  This arrangement allowed her to occasionally save some of her own money.", "refs": "[\"Kate Clifford Larson \\\"Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero\\\" pg 63\",\"Catherine Clinton \\\"Harriet Tubman: The Road to Freedom\\\" pg 23, 29\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\"]", "pic": "5657712503291904", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1840", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-12T21:06:13Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5657712503291904", "modified": "2019-02-12T21:06:13Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht05"},{"tags": "", "text": "Araminta marries John Tubman, a free black man.  She changes her name to Harriet.", "refs": "[\"Catherine Clinton \\\"Harriet Tubman: The Road to Freedom\\\" pg62\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1844", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-12T22:31:46Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5713050069893120", "modified": "2019-02-12T22:31:46Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht06"},{"tags": "", "text": "Harriet Tubman's master dies. Her three older sisters are sold, separating them from the family forever.  Her mother hides Moses, the youngest of the family for a month, then ultimately defends him in her house against her master and a slave trader saying \"You are after my son; but the first man that comes into my house, I will split his head open.\"  Moses is not sold.  Harriet escapes, traveling 90 miles to the free state of Pennsylvania along the underground railroad.  She finds work as a domestic and a cook, avoiding slave catchers and saving all the money she can.", "refs": "[\"http://www.harriet-tubman.org/timeline/\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero"\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\"]", "pic": "5645937472962560", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1849", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-12T22:36:46Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5645937472962560", "modified": "2019-03-19T20:09:03Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht07"},{"tags": "", "text": "Through her sources in the free black, fugitive black, and liberal white communities, Tubman receives word that her niece and two children will be auctioned.  Tubman travels to Baltimore, and plans a rescue with her niece Kessiah's husband John Bowley.  Bowley places the winning bid for his wife and children, then escapes with them to a nearby house without settling payment.  From there he sails with them in a small boat to Baltimore, where Tubman takes them to Philadelphia.", "refs": "[\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg89\",\"Catherine Clinton "Harriet Tubman: The Road to Freedom" pg81\",\"http://www.harriet-tubman.org/timeline/\"]", "pic": "5705261306085376", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1850-12", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-15T19:31:18Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5705261306085376", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:36:07Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht08"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Fugitive Slave Law, passed as part of the Compromise of 1850, makes escape from slavery much more difficult and dangerous.  The law enabled any slave holder with a sworn affidavit of ownership to enlist the help of law enforcement, even in free states.  The law also  denied jury trial or testimony from anyone captured.  Any person aiding a runaway slave was subject to steep fines and imprisonment.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fugitive_Slave_Act_of_1850\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compromise_of_1850\"]", "pic": "5645012914143232", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1850-09", "qtype": "U", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-18T17:12:03Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5645012914143232", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:33:53Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht09"},{"tags": "", "text": "Tubman makes two more rescue trips to Baltimore, saving her brother Moses and several others. Then she goes back to Maryland's Eastern Shore to fetch her husband, but finds he has moved on and remarried. Initially angry and hurt, she decides to let him go.  Rather than wasting the trip, she gathers several slaves and guides them to freedom.  She moves her base of operations to St. Catherines, Ontario, Canada. \"I wouldn't trust Uncle Sam with my people no longer, I brought them all clear off to Canada.\"", "refs": "[\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg91\",\"https://harriettubmancanada.com/index.html\"]", "pic": "5674844079259648", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1851", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-18T17:46:33Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5674844079259648", "modified": "2019-02-18T17:46:33Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht10"},{"tags": "", "text": "Tubman continues her missions, rescuing approximately 70 individuals, including her brothers and her elderly parents.  After meeting John Brown, she helps recruit supporters for the Harper's Ferry Attack.  Already known as \"Moses\" from her slave rescues, Brown refers to her as \"General Tubman\".", "refs": "[\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg157\",\"http://www.harriet-tubman.org/timeline/\"]", "pic": "5700291089399808", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1852-1860", "qtype": "U", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-18T22:52:48Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5700291089399808", "modified": "2019-02-26T19:31:44Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht11"},{"tags": "", "text": "Concerned for the well-being of her parents through the Canadian winters, Tubman purchases a 7 acre farm in Auburn, New York from abolitionist Senator William H Seward.  At the time, property ownership by a woman was unusual, black people were not citizens, and Tubman was legally a fugitive slave.  Seward provides favorable mortgage terms.", "refs": "[\"http://www.harriet-tubman.org/house/\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg165\"]", "pic": "5630142764285952", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1859", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-18T22:54:38Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5630142764285952", "modified": "2019-02-18T22:54:38Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht12"},{"tags": "", "text": "Tubman gives lectures and holds fundraising receptions around central New York and Boston.  While in Troy, New York, on April 27, an alarm is raised in the community for a fugitive slave Charles Nalle, who has been captured.  Tubman joins the growing crowd outside the U.S. commissioner's office, then disguises herself as an old woman and gains access to the building to signal when Nalle is moved.  Tubman fights to free Nalle and is badly beaten in the violent struggles between the rescuers and federal officers.  After several attempts, she finally manages to get to Nalle, carrying him out \"acrossed my shoulder like a bag o' meal\".", "refs": "[\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg179\",\"Catherine Clinton "Harriet Tubman: The Road to Freedom" pg137\"]", "pic": "5143335769473024", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1860", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-18T22:59:45Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5143335769473024", "modified": "2019-02-19T21:50:31Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht13"},{"tags": "", "text": "After arranging care for her parents, Tubman joins the civil war effort to help former slaves become self-sufficient.  She runs an \"eating house\" and a \"wash house\", hiring others to help while she volunteers as a nurse.  Through her work interactions and contacts in the black community, Tubman gleans information on rebel locations and movements which she passes on to Generals Sherman, Stevens, and Hunter.  She begins scouting, acting as a spy behind enemy lines, while training and leading others.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg207\"]", "pic": "5640077560512512", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1862", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-20T15:15:57Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5640077560512512", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:40:56Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht14"},{"tags": "", "text": "Tubman becomes the first woman to plan and execute an armed expedition during the Civil War.  The Combahee River Raid rescues 756 slaves and captures thousands of dollars worth of supplies.  Tubman is hailed as a heroine, but she is denied compensation for her service, and does not receive a military pension until she is 77 years old.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg215\"]", "pic": "5708345528811520", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1863-06-01", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-20T15:17:31Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5708345528811520", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:44:36Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht15"},{"tags": "", "text": "Franklin Sanborn, who helped fund John Brown, writes the first biographical account of Tubman's life, publishing his essay in the abolitionist newspaper The Boston Commonwealth.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_Benjamin_Sanborn\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg219\"]", "pic": "5664922973241344", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1863-07-17", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-20T15:19:16Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5664922973241344", "modified": "2019-02-20T15:19:16Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht16"},{"tags": "", "text": "On furlough from the Union army, Tubman meets Sojourner Truth in Boston.  With much in common, they initially disagree on Lincoln.  Tubman later explained \"we colored people didn't understand then he was our friend.  All we knew was that the first colored troops sent south from Massachusetts only got seven dollars a month, while the white regiments got fifteen.  We didn't like that.\"", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sojourner_Truth\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg226\"]", "pic": "5113134163427328", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1864-08", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-20T15:21:29Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5113134163427328", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:45:03Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht17"},{"tags": "", "text": "After the war, Tubman returns to her Auburn house, having been violently assaulted by a train conductor and two other men who broke her arm and injured her shoulder and ribs.  She cares for her parents as best she can, taking in boarders to help get money for food.  One of the boarders is Nelson Charles Davis, a veteran of the 8th United States Colored Infantry.  Four years later in 1869 they marry.  In 1874 they adopt a baby girl, Gertie Davis.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg232,260\"]", "pic": "5711670806577152", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1865", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-20T15:24:37Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5711670806577152", "modified": "2019-03-18T21:31:05Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht18"},{"tags": "", "text": "Sarah H. Bradford writes \"Scenes in the Life of Harriet Tubman\" incorporating letters from many of Tubman's associates.  Frederick Douglass wrote \"Most that I have done and suffered in the service of our cause has been in public, and I have received much encouragement at every step of the way. You, on the other hand, have labored in a private way. I have wrought in the day - you in the night. ... The midnight sky and the silent stars have been the witnesses of your devotion to freedom and of your heroism.\" Excluding the letters, the book has errors and is highly interpretive.  A second edition, \"Harriet, the Moses of Her People\" released in 1886 has similar problems.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg242,264\"]", "pic": "5677324355764224", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1868", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-20T22:31:14Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5677324355764224", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:47:26Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht19"},{"tags": "", "text": "Tubman devotes the remainder of her life to caring for others in the area around where she lives.  Despite frequently struggling to get by, she and her husband take in others who need help.  Over the years they suffer several setbacks, occasionally running out of resources and even food.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg234, 239, 255, 261\",\"Catherine Clinton "Harriet Tubman: The Road to Freedom" pg195, 200\"]", "pic": "5667383922393088", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1869", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-24T19:13:12Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5667383922393088", "modified": "2019-02-24T19:13:12Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht20"},{"tags": "", "text": "Tubman's husband dies of tuberculosis.  With no pension of her own, Tubman applies for a widow's pension based on her husband's service.  After 5 years of extensive validation procedures, she is finally granted a pension of $8/month.  New York congressman Sereno E. Payne introduces a bill to pay Harriet Tubman, finally managing to get her an additional $12/month for her services as a nurse.  Her services as a scout and spy are not considered for her pension.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\",\"http://www.harriet-tubman.org/facts/\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg277\",\"Catherine Clinton "Harriet Tubman: The Road to Freedom" pg205\"]", "pic": "5742397807919104", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1888", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-24T19:18:47Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5742397807919104", "modified": "2019-02-24T19:18:47Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht21"},{"tags": "", "text": "25 acres adjacent to Tubman's property are put up for auction, and she places the winning bid, determined to create an institution for poor and sick African Americans.  Asked how she will possibly pay for it, she responds \"I'm going home to tell the Lord Jesus all about it.\"  She immediately begins fundraising through her contacts, and requests a new edition of her biography.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman_National_Historical_Park\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg280\"]", "pic": "5679778661138432", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1896", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-24T19:21:18Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5679778661138432", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:48:10Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht22"},{"tags": "", "text": "Tubman speaks on \"More Homes for our Aged Ones\" at the National Association of Colored Women, an organization formed in response to racism within the National American Woman Suffrage Association.  In November she takes the stage with Susan B. Anthony at a suffrage convention in Rochester, New York.  In her speech she says \"I was a conductor on the Underground Railroad for eight years, and I can say what most conductors can't say - I never ran my train off the track and I never lost a passenger.\"", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg275\"]", "pic": "5740329646948352", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1896-07", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-24T22:43:37Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5740329646948352", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:49:30Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht23"},{"tags": "", "text": "No longer able to sleep due to the pain from her head injury, Tubman goes to a hospital to have her skull sawed open and raised up from where it had been crushed in.  She refuses anesthetic and bites on a bullet while praying.", "refs": "[\"http://www.harriet-tubman.org/facts/\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg282\"]", "pic": "5701325169885184", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1898", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-24T22:45:26Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5701325169885184", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:52:22Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht24"},{"tags": "", "text": "Unable to adequately fund the effort for her elderly care home, Tubman donates the property to the AME Zion Church in 1903.  The Harriet Tubman Home for Aged and Infirm Negroes officially opens in 1908.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman_National_Historical_Park\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg284\"]", "pic": "5179447854497792", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1903", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-24T22:50:16Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5179447854497792", "modified": "2019-02-24T22:50:16Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht25"},{"tags": "", "text": "Having lost the use of her legs the previous year, Tubman becomes ill and enters the Harriet Tubman Home for the Aged herself, despite not having any money.  Neighbors physically get her to the home, while friends and family raise money for her care.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg288\"]", "pic": "5752241604526080", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1911", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-24T23:12:34Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5752241604526080", "modified": "2019-02-24T23:12:34Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht26"},{"tags": "", "text": "At 91, Harriet Tubman dies of pneumonia.  She is buried with a crucifix in her hands, with her medal from Queen Victoria in her casket which is draped with an American Flag.  Her grave is marked by two small pine trees.  A gravestone marker is erected in 1937 by the Empire State Federation of Women's Clubs.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg289\"]", "pic": "5682246254067712", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1913-03-10", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-24T23:14:14Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5682246254067712", "modified": "2019-02-24T23:14:14Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht27"},{"tags": "", "text": "Earl Conrad's biography \"Harriet Tubman: Negro Soldier and Abolishonist\" is published.  Started in 1938, Conrad is able to interview individuals who knew Tubman when she was alive, documenting many aspects of her life that would otherwise have been lost.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman\",\"Kate Clifford Larson "Bound For the Promised Land: Harriet Tubman, Portrait of an American Hero" pg291\"]", "pic": "5700911208857600", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1943", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-24T23:16:48Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5700911208857600", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:57:00Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht28"},{"tags": "", "text": "A commemorative 13 cent stamp honoring Harriet Tubman is released.  On June 29 1995, a 32 cent stamp of her is released.\r\n", "refs": "[\"https://about.usps.com/publications/pub354/welcome.htm\"]", "pic": "5670766611791872", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1978-02-01", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-25T14:33:03Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5670766611791872", "modified": "2019-02-27T01:54:51Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht29"},{"tags": "", "text": "President George H. W. Bush proclaims March 10 Harriet Tubman day to \"remember her commitment to freedom and rededicate ourselves to the timeless principles she struggled to uphold\".", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Tubman_Day\"]", "pic": "5673251619471360", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1990", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-25T14:34:04Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5673251619471360", "modified": "2019-02-25T14:34:04Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ht30"}]

subtitle: 10 minutes of selected historical points from his life.
name: César Estrada Chávez
title: César Estrada Chávez
preb: [{"tags": "", "text": "C\u00e9sar Estrada Ch\u00e1vez is born in the North Gila Valley outside Yuma, Arizona. He is the second of six children. His parents, Librado Ch\u00e1vez and Juana Estrada Ch\u00e1vez run a general store and a family farm.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"https://cesarchavez2015.weebly.com/family.html\"]", "pic": "5742816500121600", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1927-03-31", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-27T22:22:59Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5742816500121600", "modified": "2019-02-27T22:22:59Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez01"},{"tags": "", "text": "When C\u00e9sar is 10 years old, his father, Librado, makes an agreement with his Anglo neighbor to clear 80 acres in exchange for the deed to 40 acres adjoining the family home. The neighbor refuses to honor the agreement and sells the land. Librado consults a lawyer, who advises him to take out a loan and purchase the land back. As the Great Depression continues, the family is unable to make payments on the loan. The lawyer who advised Librado then purchases the land, and sells it back to the original owner.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\""The Story of Cesar Chavez". United Farm Workers. https://web.archive.org/web/20100305004101/http://www.ufw.org/_page.php?menu=research&inc=history%2F07.html\"]", "pic": "5735369295265792", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1937", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-27T22:26:43Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5735369295265792", "modified": "2019-02-27T22:26:43Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez02"},{"tags": "", "text": "Having lost their farm, store, and home, the Ch\u00e1vez family moves to California, first to La Colonia Barrio in Oxnard, then to San Jose where they lived in a barrio called Sal Si Puedes - \"Get Out If You Can.\" The family picked peas and lettuce in the winter, cherries and beans in the spring, corn and grapes in the summer, and cotton in the fall. C\u00e9sar changes schools as the family changes locations. In school, C\u00e9sar faces segregation and is punished for speaking Spanish.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\""The Story of Cesar Chavez". United Farm Workers. https://web.archive.org/web/20100305004101/http://www.ufw.org/_page.php?menu=research&inc=history%2F07.html\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1938", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-27T22:50:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5172419341844480", "modified": "2019-03-22T19:37:52Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez03"},{"tags": "", "text": "Chavez joins the navy, where he encounters labor segregation preventing advancement of Mexican-Americans. While on leave, he refuses to move from the \"whites only\" section of a movie theater and is arrested for the first time.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"http://www.criticalcommons.org/Members/cmarez/clips/delano-my-home.mp4/view\"]", "pic": "5738466402893824", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1944", "qtype": "U", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-28T01:30:28Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5738466402893824", "modified": "2019-03-22T19:38:28Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez04"},{"tags": "", "text": "C\u00e9sar's father is hurt in a car accident. C\u00e9sar does not want his mother to have to work the fields while his father is hurt, so he leaves school to become a full-time farm worker.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"https://www.cpp.edu/~oslcc/cecche/the-life-of-cesar-e-chavez.shtml\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1942", "qtype": "C", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-28T17:56:06Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5719677699358720", "modified": "2019-03-22T19:37:06Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez05"},{"tags": "", "text": "After his Navy service, C\u00e9sar returns to work as a laborer. He dates Helen Fabela who was also a farm worker. Two years later they are married and settle in Delano, California.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_Fabela_Ch%C3%A1vez\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\"]", "pic": "5175516449472512", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1946", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-28T19:08:53Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5175516449472512", "modified": "2019-02-28T19:09:33Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez06"},{"tags": "", "text": "Chavez and his wife Helen are among the first parishoners of Father Donald McDonnell, who establishes a ministry in Sal Si Puedes. Chavez helps out with the church, and drives McDonnell to perform mass for bracero and county prisoners. McDonnel introduces Chavez to the writings of St. Francis of Assisi, M.K. Gandhi and other books about spirituality, labor leaders, and political philosophy.", "refs": "[\"https://ufw.org/Father-McDonnell-introduced-a-young-Cesar-Chavez-to-social-justice-teachings/\",\"https://www.biography.com/news/cesar-chavez-biography-facts\",\"https://www.ncronline.org/news/people/priest-who-inspired-cesar-chavez-dies-age-88\"]", "pic": "5733612049661952", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1950s", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-28T19:31:48Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5733612049661952", "modified": "2019-03-20T21:53:49Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez07"},{"tags": "", "text": "The mostly Filipino American members of the AFL-CIO affiliated Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee, walk out on strike against Delano-area grape growers. They ask Chavez's largely Latino NFWA to join the walkouts. On September 16, Mexican Independence Day, the NFWA, with 1,200 member families, votes to join the walkout, beginning the five-year Delano Grape Strike. Latino and Filipino strikers work together, sharing picketlines, strike kitchens and a union hall. Chavez asks strikers to take a solemn vow to remain nonviolent.", "refs": "[\"https://ufw.org/1965-1970-delano-grape-strike-boycott/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"https://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/eclipsed-cesar-chavez-larry-itliongs-story-now-emerges-n423336\",\"https://www.sfchronicle.com/opinion/article/50-years-after-the-Delano-grape-strike-6508846.php\"]", "pic": "5638062893694976", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as,Asian American", "date": "1965-09-08", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:23Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5638062893694976", "modified": "2019-03-22T19:27:51Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L70"},{"tags": "", "text": "C\u00e9sar Chavez leaves the Community Service Organization and co-founds the National Farm Workers Association with Dolores Huerta, a fellow CSO organizer. Huerta comes up with the slogan \"S\u00ed, se puede\" (\"Yes, it is possible\"). C\u00e9sar's brother Richard and his cousin Manuel come up with the flag design, borrowing the symbol of the eagle from the Aztecs. They begin organizing, using grassroots, door-to-door, house meeting tactics.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Farm_Workers\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dolores_Huerta\",\"http://www.takepart.com/article/2014/04/02/cultural-history-ufw-flag\"]", "pic": "5149972878065664", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1962", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:14Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5149972878065664", "modified": "2019-03-01T02:25:31Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L65"},{"tags": "", "text": "The UFW grape strike gains momentum and the boycott goes national, with picketing throughout the country and mayors of major cities pledging support. Ce\u0301sar Chavez begins a 25 day fast to rededicate the strikers to nonviolence. In all, an estimated 17 million American consumers go without grapes to support the workers. By 1970, table grape growers have all finally signed their first union contracts.", "refs": "[\"https://ufw.org/1965-1970-delano-grape-strike-boycott/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\""The Story of Cesar Chavez". United Farm Workers. https://web.archive.org/web/20100305004101/http://www.ufw.org/_page.php?menu=research&inc=history%2F07.html\"]", "pic": "5719418969522176", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as,Asian American", "date": "1968-02", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:31Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5719418969522176", "modified": "2019-03-01T18:59:40Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L74"},{"tags": "", "text": "6000 drivers and packing workers represented by the Teamsters go on strike, refusing to pack or deliver lettuce. A week later the strike ends with a contract giving the Teamsters, not the UFW, access to farms and the right to organize workers into unions. By August, negotiations and agreements between the UFW and the Teamsters break down. Ch\u00e1vez and the UFW disobey court orders and begin picketing.\r\n", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_Bowl_strike\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\"]", "pic": "5191872163086336", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1970-07-17", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:37Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5191872163086336", "modified": "2019-03-20T18:52:35Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L78"},{"tags": "", "text": "Chavez begins a 24 day fast at the Santa Rita Hall in Phoenix, after Arizona Governor Jack Williams signs a new law essentially banning the right of farm workers to strike, boycott, or organize. Chavez helps to replace Jack Williams with Ra\u00fal H\u00e9ctor Castro in 1974.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"https://www.nytimes.com/1972/05/21/archives/chavez-continues-a-fast-in-arizona-protests-farm-labor-law-mcgovern.html\",\"http://chavez.cde.ca.gov/ResearchCenter/DocumentDisplayRC.aspx?rpg=/chdocuments/documentdisplay.jsp&doc=6bec47%3Aea792358ca%3A-7ac7&searchhit=yes\",\"http://barriozona.com/cesar-e-chavez-in-phoenix-1972-fast-at-the-santa-rita-hall/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1974_Arizona_gubernatorial_election\"]", "pic": "5691423567380480", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1972-05-12", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:41Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5691423567380480", "modified": "2019-03-20T18:18:56Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L79"},{"tags": "", "text": "Fighting to gain legal protections for farm workers, the UFW organizes a 110 mile march from San Francisco to the E&J Gallo Winery in Modesto. Starting with a few hundred people, over fifteen thousand join the march en route. The show of support helps pass the California Agricultural Labor Relations Act (ALRA) guaranteeing collective bargaining for farm workers. Chavez leads a 59 day, thousand mile march through the state to educate workers about their new rights.", "refs": "[\"https://ufw.org/research/history/ufw-chronology/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Agricultural_Labor_Relations_Act\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_Bowl_strike\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\"]", "pic": "5121103718514688", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1974-1975", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:49Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5121103718514688", "modified": "2019-03-22T19:40:52Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L85"},{"tags": "", "text": "The inadequately funded California Agricultural Labor Relations Board (ALRB) is forced to close mid-year. Chavez gathers signatures to place Proposition 14 on the ballot, allowing organizers access to workers. Prop 14 is defeated, and the failure becomes a catalyst for rifts in the UFW. Chavez opposes local UFW unions, fires many members for perceived disloyalty, employs cult leadership techniques, and endorses Ferdinand Marcos in ill-advised effort to reach out to Filipino-American farmworkers. UFW membership falls.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\"]", "pic": "5078385973788672", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1976", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:14Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5078385973788672", "modified": "2019-03-25T16:51:57Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L97"},{"tags": "", "text": "Chavez begins the \"Wrath of Grapes\" campaign to draw public attention to the pesticide poisoning of farm workers, their children, and consumers. In July of 1988, at age 61, Chavez begins a fast lasting 36 days before others convince him to eat again. The fast causes health problems that may have contributed to his death.", "refs": "[\"https://ufw.org/research/history/ufw-chronology/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"http://www.emersonkent.com/speeches/wrath_of_grapes_boycott.htm\",\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wq48o4ftL4A\"]", "pic": "6244412283682816", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1986-05", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:21Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6244412283682816", "modified": "2019-03-21T15:42:12Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L99"},{"tags": "", "text": "Ce\u0301sar Chavez dies of natural causes. His family donates his black nylon union jacket to the National Museum of American History.", "refs": "[\"https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/when-union-leader-cesar-chavez-organized-nations-farmworkers-changed-history-70776286/\",\"https://ufw.org/research/history/ufw-chronology/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\"]", "pic": "6609953594802176", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1993-04-23", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:38Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6609953594802176", "modified": "2019-03-21T16:09:55Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L107"},{"tags": "", "text": "A year after C\u00e9sar Chavez's death, President Bill Clinton posthumously presents Chavez with the Medal of Freedom, America's highest civilian honor. Helen Chavez accepts the award, and UFW president Arturo Rodriguez thanks Clinton on behalf of the union. Clinton says Chavez \"faced formidable, often violent opposition with dignity and nonviolence. And he was victorious. Cesar Chavez left our world better than he found it, and his legacy inspires us still.\"", "refs": "[\"http://chavez.cde.ca.gov/ResearchCenter/DocumentDisplayRC.aspx?rpg=/chdocuments/documentdisplay.jsp&doc=6212dd%3Aead754e3ce%3A-7f24\"]", "pic": "4653242998849536", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1994-08-08", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:42Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4653242998849536", "modified": "2019-03-28T16:38:47Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L110"},{"tags": "", "text": "President Obama proclaims March 31, C\u00e9sar Chavez's birthday, a federal commemorative holiday. California first recognized C\u00e9sar Chavez Day as a paid holiday for state employees in 2000. Other states observe C\u00e9sar Chavez Day as a paid holiday, recognized optional holiday, or cause for festivities.", "refs": "[\"http://www.cesarchavezholiday.org/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez_Day\"]", "pic": "6037109110472704", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "2014", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:10:01Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6037109110472704", "modified": "2019-03-22T19:54:46Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L124"},{"tags": "", "text": "Chavez meets Fred Ross, a community organizer who describes how poor people can build power. Ross is one of the founders of the Community Service Organization, a Latino civil rights group fighting police brutality, registering voters, and improving conditions for farmworkers. Soon after meeting, Ross convinces Saul Alinsky to hire Chavez as a full time organizer. Chavez begins traveling throughout California urging Mexican Americans to vote and speaking on worker's rights. In 1958 he becomes CSO's national director and organizes protests against abuses of the bracero system.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Ross\",\"https://www.zinnedproject.org/materials/ross-fred/\",\"https://www.thenation.com/article/meet-the-long-forgotten-organizer-who-inspired-cesar-chavez-to-become-an-activist/\"]", "pic": "5748323621273600", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1952", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-02-28T22:26:58Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5748323621273600", "modified": "2019-02-28T22:26:58Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez08"},{"tags": "", "text": "Members and supporters of the NFWA begin a 300 mile march from Delano to Sacramento. The theme of pilgrimage, penance, and revolution ends with over 8000 farmworkers and supporters crossing the Tower Bridge in Sacramento.
