In August, the AFL-CIO charters the United Farm Workers, officially combining the AWOC and the NFWA.\r\n", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Farm_Workers\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Itliong\",\"https://libraries.ucsd.edu/farmworkermovement/essays/essays/MillerArchive/016%20Letter%20From%20Cesar%20Chavez%20To%20Friends.pdf\",\"https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2016/04/11/ufw1-a11.html\",\"https://tavaana.org/en/en/content/fighting-farm-workers-rights-cesar-chavez-delano-grape-strike-and-boycott\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delano_grape_strike\"]", "pic": "5668624027090944", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as,Asian American", "date": "1966-03-17", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2019-03-01T14:25:00Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5668624027090944", "modified": "2019-03-22T20:05:44Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez09"},{"tags": "", "text": "The UFW asks consumers to join in a nationwide boycott of non-union lettuce. Violent confrontations begin to occur in the fields. A regional UFW office is bombed. Ch\u00e1vez is arrested and imprisoned. Strikes, boycotts, and violent confrontations continue for 6 months until March 26 when the Teamsters and UFW sign a jurisdictional agreement reaffirming the UFW's right to organize field workers.", "refs": "[\"https://clarksdalenews.com/2-day-in-civil-rights-7/\",\"https://www.nytimes.com/1970/12/05/archives/chavez-is-jailed-in-lettuce-strike-held-in-contempt-he-defies-order.html\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_Bowl_strike\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\"]", "pic": "5764506789609472", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1970-09", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-03-20T18:10:25Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5764506789609472", "modified": "2019-03-22T19:29:31Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez10"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Teamsters break their agreement with the UFW. UFW picketing resumes and is met with violence. Firebombs are thrown at UFW picket lines, and some UFW members are shot. In August, Chavez enters into talks with the Teamsters. The talks collapse, but resume after the Teamsters repudiate their existing contracts. In September the Teamsters agree once again to leave jurisdiction over farm field workers to the UFW.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_Bowl_strike\",\"https://libraries.ucsd.edu/farmworkermovement/ufwarchives/DuePearcyCollection/Why%20We%20Boycott.pdf\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"https://ufw.org/research/history/ufw-chronology/\"]", "pic": "5096478682906624", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1972-12", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-03-20T18:56:36Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5096478682906624", "modified": "2019-03-21T16:47:01Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez11"},{"tags": "", "text": "The UFW begins to regroup and strikes lettuce and vegetable growers throughout the state, winning several contract improvements. Two strikers are shot and killed by grower agents. Growers back George Deukmejian for Governor, and his appointees shut down enforcement of the state farm labor law. Chavez declares a third grape boycott.", "refs": "[\"https://ufw.org/research/history/ufw-chronology/\"]", "pic": "5716796984262656", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1979-1984", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-03-21T15:27:16Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5716796984262656", "modified": "2019-03-25T16:52:42Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez12"},{"tags": "", "text": "On the 10th anniversary of Chavez' passing, the United States Postal Service issues a commemorative stamp honoring his life's work and legacy", "refs": "[\"https://about.usps.com/postal-bulletin/2003/html/pb22100/kit2.html\"]", "pic": "5153847030841344", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "2003-04-23", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2019-03-21T16:45:53Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5153847030841344", "modified": "2019-03-21T16:45:53Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "chavez13"}]

subtitle: A 5 minute overview from "Pilgrims and Indians" to pardoning turkeys.
name: Thanksgiving
title: U.S. Thanksgiving
preb: [{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "13 years before Pilgrims, the first English settlers found Jamestown (Virginia). They settle in Tsenacommacah (\"densely inhabited Land\") of the Powhatan People, a confederation unified by mamanatowick (paramount chief) Wahunsunacawh.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamestown%2C_Virginia\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Powhatan\"]", "pic": "5755685136498688", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1607", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:02Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5755685136498688", "modified": "2018-11-16T18:37:17Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N178"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "Pilgrims arrive in Provincetown MA. Unable to sustain themselves, they take corn from Native American gravesites. Fearing reprisal for the theft of corn and having shot at some of the Native Americans they ran into near Eastham, the Pilgrims leave for a new site and settle at a recently abandoned Native American settlement called Patuxet. The area was referred to as \"New Plymouth\" in maps published by John Smith in 1614, so they called their settlement Plymouth.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mourt's_Relation\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1620-11", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:04Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5706803308396544", "modified": "2018-11-18T19:53:37Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N21"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "King Phillips War: The fragile peace negotiated between the Wampanoag confederacy and the Pilgrims falls apart, not only from disease pandemics but also from disregard by boatloads of new arrivals who fail to honor the terms of negotiated agreements that respected Indian rights and culture. Metacomet (aka King Philip, second son of Ousamequin), gathers some 20,000 Native Americans who fight for a year against the New England colonists but fail to win back their country. The war is one of the bloodiest and most costly in the history of America. Hundreds of Natives who fought with Philip are sold into slavery abroad, others (especially women and children) are forced into servitude locally.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_Philip%27s_War\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wampanoag\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1675-06-1676-08", "qtype": "C", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:06Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5189804673204224", "modified": "2018-11-19T15:37:44Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N26"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "Fearing the Naragansett will side with Metacomet in the spring, colonial militia attack the Great Swamp fort near Kingston, Rhode Island. In addition to killing Naragansett warriors, the militia destroy their winter stores and kill hundreds of women and children.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Swamp_Fight\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narragansett_people\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wampanoag\"]", "pic": "5171105190903808", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1675-12-19", "qtype": "C", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:07Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5171105190903808", "modified": "2018-11-12T19:14:45Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N27"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "Samoset, an English speaking Abenaki from Maine, becomes the first Native person to visit the Pilgrim's village when he drops by for a beer. Next week he returns with Tisquantum (Squanto), an English speaking Wampanoag who befriends the English, showing them how to plant corn, fish and gather berries and nuts. Later that month, the Pilgrims enter into a treaty of mutual protection with Pokanoket Wampanoag leader Ousamequin, also called Massasoit (\"Great Sachem\").", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samoset\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squanto\"]", "pic": "5176513225818112", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1621-03-16", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-10T20:00:14Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5176513225818112", "modified": "2018-11-16T20:54:54Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday1"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "After reaping their first harvest, the Pilgrims send men out fowling to supplement their feast. Ousamequin (Massasoit), hearing of large amounts of gunfire, takes 90 men to aid the village and is invited to feast instead. Realizing there is not enough food, he sends his men out hunting and they return with five deer to contribute to the 3 day event.", "refs": "[\"https://newsmaven.io/indiancountrytoday/archive/the-wampanoag-side-of-the-first-thanksgiving-story-TmMLTgQs40aJT_n9T3RMIQ/\",\"https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2015/11/151121-first-thanksgiving-pilgrims-native-americans-wampanoag-saints-and-strangers/\",\"http://www.pilgrimhallmuseum.org/pdf/TG_What_Happened_in_1621.pdf\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanksgiving_(United_States)\"]", "pic": "5656976453271552", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1621-10", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-10T20:03:30Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5656976453271552", "modified": "2018-11-14T21:14:19Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday2"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "Plymouth Mass officials invite a Wampanoag man, Frank James, to speak at Thanksgiving festivities, requesting he provide his speech in advance. The officials disapprove of James' historically accurate account of contact between colonialists and Native Americans, so they provide their own speech for him to read instead. Frank James refuses to read their speech and instead begins the National Day of Mourning, a yearly observance at Plymouth, MA commemorating the social and political struggles of native people.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Day_of_Mourning_(United_States_protest)\",\"http://uaine.org/suppressed_speech.htm\"]", "pic": "5643365970345984", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1970", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:36Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5643365970345984", "modified": "2018-11-19T17:12:28Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N124"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "In a letter to his daughter Sarah, Benjamin Franklin compares the respectability and morality of the Bald Eagle and the Turkey, regretting the choice of the eagle and pointing out that a \"little King Bird not bigger than a Sparrow\" can attack it and drive it away. In comparison he notes that the Turkey is \"though a little vain & silly, a Bird of Courage\".", "refs": "[\"https://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/american-myths-benjamin-franklins-turkey-and-the-presidential-seal-6623414/\",\"https://www.fi.edu/benjamin-franklin-faq\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin\"]", "pic": "5719378301550592", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "", "date": "1784-01-26", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-11T17:54:18Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5719378301550592", "modified": "2018-11-11T23:20:40Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday3"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "After starving during the winter and resorting to cannibalism to survive, Jamestown colonists hold a thanksgiving service to celebrate the arrival of supply ships.", "refs": "[\"https://strangeremains.com/2013/11/28/the-thanksgiving-of-1610-in-jamestown-was-a-celebration-of-the-end-of-the-starving-time-and-probably-cannibalism/\",\"http://history.org/Foundation/journal/Winter07/jamestown.cfm\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanksgiving_(United_States)\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "", "date": "1610", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-11T20:51:11Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5764748591235072", "modified": "2018-11-19T15:23:45Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday4"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "The Continental Congress declares the upcoming Thursday Nov 28 to be observed as \"a day of solemn THANKSGIVING to GOD\". Similar declarations follow in 1789, 1795, 1798, 1799, 1814, 1815, and 1863, thereafter the holiday is observed annually on the last Thursday of November.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanksgiving_(United_States)\",\"https://www.loc.gov/teachers/classroommaterials/presentationsandactivities/presentations/thanksgiving\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "", "date": "1782-10-11", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-11T20:58:33Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5175650340044800", "modified": "2018-11-12T20:27:19Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday5"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "Following the decision to separate from Britain and engage in the Revolutionary War, the First National Proclamation of Thanksgiving is given by the Continental Congress, declaring the upcoming Thursday December 18 to be set apart \"for Solemn Thanksgiving and Praise\", primarily for \"the Prosecution of a just and necessary War\".", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanksgiving_(United_States)\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "", "date": "1777", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-11T23:05:10Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5734792670740480", "modified": "2018-11-19T15:39:06Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday6"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "With 5 Thursdays in November, President Roosevelt moves Thanksgiving to the next-to-last Thursday, allowing merchants more time to sell goods before Christmas. At the time, advertising for Christmas before Thanksgiving was considered inappropriate.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanksgiving_(United_States)\"]", "pic": "5647591547076608", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "", "date": "1939", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-11T23:15:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5647591547076608", "modified": "2018-11-19T16:32:16Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": ""},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "Thanksgiving is officially declared to the fourth Thursday in November, regardless of how many Thursdays the month has that year, starting in 1942.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanksgiving_(United_States)\"]", "pic": "5633494390669312", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "", "date": "1941", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-11T23:16:33Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5633494390669312", "modified": "2018-11-12T00:59:32Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday7"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "The first Thanksgiving Day football game takes place in Philadelphia, PA. beginning a tradition that continues to this day. The NFL is formed in 1920, and operates as a nonprofit until 2015 with the tax code explicitly exempting professional football leagues. The ball evolves its shape from inadequate inflation.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League\",\"https://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/how-did-the-pigskin-get-its-shape-63180450/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_football_on_Thanksgiving\"]", "pic": "5673497447628800", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "", "date": "1869", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-12T00:05:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5673497447628800", "modified": "2018-11-19T16:31:37Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday9"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "President Abraham Lincoln's son Tad intercedes on behalf of a live turkey brought home for Christmas dinner.\r\n", "refs": "[\"https://www.whitehousehistory.org/pardoning-the-thanksgiving-turkey\"]", "pic": "5670249378611200", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "", "date": "1863", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-12T01:02:12Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5670249378611200", "modified": "2018-11-12T01:02:12Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday10"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "President John F. Kennedy responds to a 55lb turkey presented by the National Turkey Federation saying \"Let's keep him going.\" sending the turkey back to its California home as it is too large for the White House. Sending gift turkeys off to farms becomes traditional.", "refs": "[\"https://www.whitehousehistory.org/pardoning-the-thanksgiving-turkey\",\"https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/Decoder/2014/1126/White-House-turkey-pardon-Did-John-F.-Kennedy-start-the-tradition\"]", "pic": "5744052955774976", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "", "date": "1963-11-19", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-12T01:03:36Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5744052955774976", "modified": "2018-11-12T20:26:49Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday11"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "President George H.W. Bush solidifies the turkey pardon tradition, remarking \"'Reprieve', 'keep him going', or 'pardon': it's all the same for the turkey, as long as he doesn\u2019t end up on the president\u2019s holiday table.\"", "refs": "[\"https://www.whitehousehistory.org/pardoning-the-thanksgiving-turkey\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "", "date": "1989", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-12T01:04:58Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5177138009341952", "modified": "2018-11-12T01:04:58Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday12"},{"tags": "", "text": "Pequot War: Fur trade conflicts between English, Mohegan, Narragansett and others against Dutch, Pequot and others lead to murders and raids, escalating to an attack on one of the Pequot fortified villages in Mystic CT. Of the estimated 500 Pequots there, 7 are taken prisoner, 7 escape, and the rest are killed.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pequot_War\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1637", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5073368378245120", "modified": "2018-11-19T17:01:01Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N23"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "Following the attack on the Pequots, Governor John Winthrop orders \"a day of publicke thanksgiving to God for his great m'cies in subdewing the Pecoits\", including the massacre of hundreds of men, women and children in Mystic.", "refs": "[\"http://nativeweb.org/pages/legal/thanksgiving_nelte.html\",\"https://nativeamericannetroots.net/diary/288\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1637-08-12", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-12T02:25:16Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5642383161032704", "modified": "2018-11-23T16:03:23Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday13"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "The annual gathering in Plymouth Mass to commemorate the 28th National Day of Mourning is met by police and state troopers. 25 people are arrested. In October of 1998, the state reaches a settlement with United American Indians of New England (UAINE) allowing them to march without a permit, providing they give the town advanced notice. The National Day of Mourning continues to this day, providing history, reports on current Native American experiences, and solidarity with oppressed peoples worldwide.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Day_of_Mourning_(United_States_protest)\",\"http://www.uaine.org/\"]", "pic": "5696068708728832", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1997", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-12T02:26:38Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5696068708728832", "modified": "2018-11-19T16:42:49Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday14"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "The first official government proclamation of Thanksgiving is made by the council of Charlestown, Massachusetts \"Beseeching that being perswaded by the mercies of God we may all, even this whole people offer up our bodies and soulds as a living and acceptable Service unto God by Jesus Christ\". Two months later Metacomet is shot and dismembered. His hands are given as trophies and his head is mounted on a pike at the entrance to the Plymouth settlement. His family is sold into slavery.", "refs": "[\"http://www.danielnpaul.com/TheRealThanksgiving.html\",\"http://www.thanksgivingnovember.com/the-first-thanksgiving-proclamation.html\",\"http://daghettotymz.com/rkyvz/articles/thanks/massacre-murder-mayhem.html\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1676-06-29", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-11-16T21:00:10Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5699414689579008", "modified": "2018-11-16T21:06:59Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "tday15"}]

subtitle: Civil Rights Champion
name: Ella Baker
title: Ella Baker
preb: [{"tags": "", "text": "Ella Josephine Baker is born in Norfolk, Virginia, the second of three children born to Georgiana and Blake Baker.  When she is 7, her family moves to Littleton, North Carolina where her mother was from.  As a girl, Ella listened to stories from her maternal grandmother, Josephine Elizabeth \"Bet\" Ross who had been born into slavery.", "refs": "[\"https://www.biography.com/people/ella-baker-9195848\",\"http://blackhistorynow.com/ella-baker/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ella_Baker\",\"Moye, J. Todd (2013). Ella Baker : Community Organizer of the Civil Rights Movement. Lanham: Rowman & Littlefield Publishers. ISBN 978-1442215658.\",\"http://www.browsebiography.com/bio-ella_baker.html\"]", "pic": "5744125232021504", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1903-12-13", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-10-01T22:15:40Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5744125232021504", "modified": "2018-10-01T22:15:40Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "eb1"},{"tags": "", "text": "Ella Baker majors in sociology and graduates as class valedictorian from Shaw University in Raleigh, North Carolina.  After graduating, she moves to New York City and works as a waitress before joining the editorial staff of the American West Indian News.  She then works as an editorial assistant at the Negro National News, and becomes national director of the Young Negroes' Cooperative League (YNCL).  She teaches courses in the Worker's Education Project of the Works Progress Administration, founds the Negro History Club at the Harlem Library, attends lectures and meetings at the YWCA and participates in political protests.\r\n", "refs": "[\"https://www.biography.com/people/ella-baker-9195848\",\"http://blackhistorynow.com/ella-baker/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ella_Baker\",\"Ransby, Barbara (1994). \\\"Ella Josephine Baker\\\". In Buhle, Mary Jo et al. The American Radical. Psychology Press. ISBN 9780415908047.\"]", "pic": "5663998322147328", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1927", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-10-01T22:17:36Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5663998322147328", "modified": "2018-10-01T22:17:36Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "eb2"},{"tags": "", "text": "Ella Baker joins the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) and is hired as a secretary in 1940.  She travels widely to raise money, recruit members and organize local chapters.  In 1943 she becomes Director of Branches, pushing the NAACP to build its strength from the discussions, debates, decisions and local actions of its members, especially young people and women.", "refs": "[\"https://www.biography.com/people/ella-baker-9195848\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ella_Baker\",\"Ransby, Barbara (2005) Ella Baker and the Black Freedom MovementA Radical Democratic Vision https://www.uncpress.org/book/9780807856161/ella-baker-and-the-black-freedom-movement/?title_id=270\",\"https://snccdigital.org/events/ella-baker-organizes-naacp-chapters/\"]", "pic": "5768939674009600", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1938", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-10-01T22:18:59Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5768939674009600", "modified": "2018-10-01T22:18:59Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "eb3"},{"tags": "", "text": "Ella Baker becomes involved in the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) helping to organize large events like the Prayer Pilgrimage for Freedom and the Crusade for Citizenship.  She works closely with southern civil rights activists and is critical of the SCLC emphasis on hierarchy.  Her views are evident describing the role of Martin Luther King, Jr., when she said that the \"movement made Martin, and not Martin the movement.\"", "refs": "[\"https://www.biography.com/people/ella-baker-9195848\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ella_Baker\",\"Ransby, Barbara (2005) Ella Baker and the Black Freedom MovementA Radical Democratic Vision https://www.uncpress.org/book/9780807856161/ella-baker-and-the-black-freedom-movement/?title_id=270\"]", "pic": "5671984008527872", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1957", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-10-01T22:20:14Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5671984008527872", "modified": "2018-10-01T22:20:14Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "eb4"},{"tags": "", "text": "Ella Baker persuades the SCLC to invite university student sit-in leaders to the Southwide Youth Leadership Conference at Shaw University where they meet and form the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC, pronounced \"snick\").  Baker encourages them to be wary of a \"leader-centered orientation\" and strives to keep them independent of the older, church-based leadership.  With Baker's help, the SNCC and the Congress of Racial Equity (CORE) coordinate the region-wide Freedom Rides of 1961.", "refs": "[\"https://www.biography.com/people/ella-baker-9195848\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ella_Baker\",\"Ransby, Barbara (2005) Ella Baker and the Black Freedom MovementA Radical Democratic Vision https://www.uncpress.org/book/9780807856161/ella-baker-and-the-black-freedom-movement/?title_id=270\"]", "pic": "5750943224168448", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1960", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-10-01T22:25:13Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5750943224168448", "modified": "2018-10-01T22:25:13Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "eb5"},{"tags": "", "text": "Ella Baker joins the staff of the Southern Conference Education Fund (SCEF) whose goal was to help black and white people work together for social justice.  SCEF raised funds for black activists, lobbied for implementation of President John F. Kennedy's civil rights proposals, and tried to educate southern whites about the evils of racism.", "refs": "[\"https://www.biography.com/people/ella-baker-9195848\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ella_Baker\",\"Ransby, Barbara (2005) Ella Baker and the Black Freedom MovementA Radical Democratic Vision https://www.uncpress.org/book/9780807856161/ella-baker-and-the-black-freedom-movement/?title_id=270\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1962", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-10-01T22:26:50Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5702907169079296", "modified": "2018-10-01T22:26:50Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "eb6"},{"tags": "", "text": "Ella Baker helps organize the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party (MFDP) as an alternative to the all-white pro-segregationist Mississippi Democratic Party.  She accompanies the MFDP to the National Democratic Party convention and challenges the official party to affirm the rights of African Americans to participate in party elections in the South.  The MFDP delegation is not seated, but their influence helps to elect black leaders in Mississippi and they force a rule change to allow women and minorities to sit as delegates at the Democratic National Convention.", "refs": "[\"https://www.biography.com/people/ella-baker-9195848\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ella_Baker\",\"Ransby, Barbara (2005) Ella Baker and the Black Freedom MovementA Radical Democratic Vision https://www.uncpress.org/book/9780807856161/ella-baker-and-the-black-freedom-movement/?title_id=270\"]", "pic": "5640311980163072", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1964", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-10-01T22:28:19Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5640311980163072", "modified": "2018-10-01T22:28:19Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "eb7"},{"tags": "", "text": "Ella Baker dies on her 83rd birthday.\r\n", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ella_Baker\",\"Ransby, Barbara (2005) Ella Baker and the Black Freedom MovementA Radical Democratic Vision https://www.uncpress.org/book/9780807856161/ella-baker-and-the-black-freedom-movement/?title_id=270\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1986-12-13", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-10-01T22:29:19Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5669165906001920", "modified": "2018-10-01T22:29:19Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "eb8"},{"tags": "", "text": "Ella Baker is honored on The Civil Rights Pioneers stamp sheet together with Ruby Hurley.", "refs": "[\"https://about.usps.com/news/national-releases/2009/sr09_020.htm\"]", "pic": "5077362026741760", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "2009-02-21", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-10-01T22:30:11Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5077362026741760", "modified": "2018-10-01T22:30:11Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "eb11"}]

comment: Knowledge of past events and patterns makes you more effective in the present. This highly condensed intro will take 2-3 hours and give you a solid framework to start from (if you're ready). [I'm Ready]
about: The starting points for U.S. Race History were compiled by Karen L. Suyemoto, Ph.D. - UMass (Boston) Psychology and Asian American Studies. The points were updated in 2005-2006 by Claudia Fox Tree and Elli Stern for EMI Empowering Multicultural Initiatives. In 2014 the points were updated again by Emily Davis, for K. Suyemoto. In 2017, Eric Parker updated the points and created supporting visualizations.
subtitle: An abbreviated introduction to the history of race and racism in the United States
name: General Introduction
title: U.S. Race History
preb: [{"tags": "", "text": "Mayan civilization flourishes in the Yucatan peninsula and Guatemala. At its peak, Teotihuaca\u0301n is one of the largest cities in the entire ancient world with over one hundred thousand people. The civilization dominates the culture of the valley of Mexico for almost a millenium and stands as the most significant cultural influence throughout the history of Central American civilizations.", "refs": "", "pic": "5651124426113024", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,Latino/as", "date": "1000 BCE", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:04:18Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5651124426113024", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:04:18Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N3"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Triple Alliance, aka the Aztec Empire, begins as an alliance of three Nahua \"altepetl\" city-states: Mexico-Tenochtitlan, Mexico-Texcoco, and Mexico-Tlacopan. They rule the area in and around the Valley of Mexico until they are defeated by the combined forces of the Spanish conquistadores and their native allies under Hern\u00e1n Cort\u00e9s in 1521.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,Latino/as", "date": "1426-1428", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:04:24Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5752754626625536", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:04:24Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N10"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Inca empire expands from the highland center Cuzco in Peru, and by the early sixteenth century excercises control over more territory than any other people had done in South American history. The empire consisted of over one million individuals, spanning a territory stretching from Ecuador to northern Chile. Unlike the military empires in Central America, the Incas ruled by proxy, incorporating local rulers into their imperial system after conquests.", "refs": "", "pic": "5734055144325120", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,Latino/as", "date": "1440's", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:04:25Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5734055144325120", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:04:25Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N11"},{"tags": "", "text": "Columbus sails and \u201cdiscovers\u201d the Americas, landing Oct 12 on a Caribbean island (probably Watling Island in the Bahamas) which he names San Salvador. Later in December, he lands on Hispaniola (which he thinks might be Japan). Some prominent crew members on the first voyage were of African descent. At the time, the Native American population is estimated to have been over 50 million.  In parts of Latin America, Columbus Day is celebrated as El D\u00eda de la Raza (The Day of the [New Mixed] Race).", "refs": "[\"https://www.britannica.com/biography/Christopher-Columbus/The-first-voyage\",\"http://www.christopher-columbus.eu/ships-crew.htm\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ni%C3%B1o_brothers\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_history_of_indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas\",\"https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/D%C3%ADa_de_la_Raza\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American,Latino/as,Multiracial", "date": "1492", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:04:26Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5631383682678784", "modified": "2019-01-31T22:16:42Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N12"},{"tags": "", "text": "Columbus initiates European enslavement of Native Americans by sending more than 500 to Spain to be sold.", "refs": "[]", "pic": "5699257587728384", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1494", "qtype": "U", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:04:31Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5699257587728384", "modified": "2018-07-11T13:02:50Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N13"},{"tags": "", "text": "Sermon of Antonio de Montesinos, O.P., in Santo Domingo, on the fourth Sunday of Advent, criticizing colonists' treatment of Native Americans. His sermon causes outrage among the conquistadors and has a formative impact upon Bartolom\u00e9 de las Casas who later becomes known for his advocacy of the rights of indigenous peoples of the Americas.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,Latino/as", "date": "1511-12-21", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:04:58Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5695159920492544", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:04:58Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L3"},{"tags": "", "text": "Slaves revolt against Spanish rule for the first time. The rebellion is quickly and harshly suppressed. The revolt is the first of many in Hispaniola. Slave revolts in the 16th century are also reported in Puerto Rico, Panama, Cuba, and Mexico.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American,Latino/as", "date": "1522", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:00Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5689413791121408", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:00Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B6"},{"tags": "", "text": "By this time, over 900,000 slaves have been brought to Latin America. In the next century, 2,750,000 are added to that total. ", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1600", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:00Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5723348596162560", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:00Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B5"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "13 years before Pilgrims, the first English settlers found Jamestown (Virginia).  They settle in Tsenacommacah (\"densely inhabited Land\") of the Powhatan People, a confederation unified by mamanatowick (paramount chief) Wahunsunacawh.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamestown%2C_Virginia\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Powhatan\"]", "pic": "5755685136498688", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1607", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:02Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5755685136498688", "modified": "2018-11-16T18:37:17Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N178"},{"tags": "", "text": "Jamestown starvation over the winter. Some settlers run off to join the Indians, while those remaining resort to cannibalism. The remaining settlers later demand the Indians return the runaways. When the Indians refuse, the settlers kill 15-16 adults, take the queen and her children into boats and kill them.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1609-1610", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:02Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5136307634307072", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:02Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N19"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "Pilgrims arrive in Provincetown MA. Unable to sustain themselves, they take corn from Native American gravesites. Fearing reprisal for the theft of corn and having shot at some of the Native Americans they ran into near Eastham, the Pilgrims leave for a new site and settle at a recently abandoned Native American settlement called Patuxet. The area was referred to as \"New Plymouth\" in maps published by John Smith in 1614, so they called their settlement Plymouth.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mourt's_Relation\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1620-11", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:04Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5706803308396544", "modified": "2018-11-18T19:53:37Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N21"},{"tags": "", "text": "First major Native American retaliation. Chief Opechancanough of the Powhatan Confederacy, leads the assault on the nearly 350 English settlers around Jamestown, Virginia.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1622", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:04Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5702666986455040", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:04Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N22"},{"tags": "", "text": "A Jamestown, Virginia court order states that \"a White man... be soundly whipped before an assemblage of Negroes and others for abusing himself to the dishonor of God and the shame of Christians by defiling his body in lying with a Negro, which fault he is to acknowledge next Sabbath day.\"", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Multiracial", "date": "1630", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:04Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5714163003293696", "modified": "2018-07-03T18:17:44Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: R2"},{"tags": "", "text": "Pequot War: Fur trade conflicts between English, Mohegan, Narragansett and others against Dutch, Pequot and others lead to murders and raids, escalating to an attack on one of the Pequot fortified villages in Mystic CT. Of the estimated 500 Pequots there, 7 are taken prisoner, 7 escape, and the rest are killed.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pequot_War\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1637", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5073368378245120", "modified": "2018-11-19T17:01:01Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N23"},{"tags": "", "text": "Spanish authorities raid Pueblo kivas (sacred ceremonial chambers) and destroy hundreds of Kachina masks and other sacred objects in an effort to destroy Native American \u201creligion.\u201d", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,Latino/as", "date": "1661", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5093108584808448", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:05Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N25"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "Fearing the Naragansett will side with Metacomet in the spring, colonial militia attack the Great Swamp fort near Kingston, Rhode Island. In addition to killing Naragansett warriors, the militia destroy their winter stores and kill hundreds of women and children.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Swamp_Fight\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narragansett_people\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wampanoag\"]", "pic": "5171105190903808", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1675-12-19", "qtype": "C", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:07Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5171105190903808", "modified": "2018-11-12T19:14:45Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N27"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "King Phillips War: The fragile peace negotiated between the Wampanoag confederacy and the Pilgrims falls apart, not only from disease pandemics but also from disregard by boatloads of new arrivals who fail to honor the terms of negotiated agreements that respected Indian rights and culture. Metacomet (aka King Philip, second son of Ousamequin), gathers some 20,000 Native Americans who fight for a year against the New England colonists but fail to win back their country. The war is one of the bloodiest and most costly in the history of America. Hundreds of Natives who fought with Philip are sold into slavery abroad, others (especially women and children) are forced into servitude locally.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_Philip%27s_War\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wampanoag\"]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1675-06-1676-08", "qtype": "C", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:06Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5189804673204224", "modified": "2018-11-19T15:37:44Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N26"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Pueblo Rebellion, incited by eighty years of harsh treatment by the Spanish, results in the massacre of over four hundred soldiers, officers, and priests. The Southwest reverts to Native American country until it is reconquered 12 years later.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,Latino/as", "date": "1680", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:07Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5068433729257472", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:07Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N29"},{"tags": "", "text": "Mennonites in Pennsylvania sign an anti-slavery resolution, the first formal protest against slavery in the Western Hemisphere.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1688", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:08Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5712536552865792", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:08Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B11"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Maiden Lane slave revolt in New York City by 23 enslaved Africans claims the lives of 9 Whites and injures another six. 70 Blacks are arrested and jailed, 21 are executed, 6 others commit suicide.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1712", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:09Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6331965594664960", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:09Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B15"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Stono Rebellion. Jemmy (a literate slave held by the Cato or Cater family in South Carolina) leads 20 other enslaved Kongolese south towards Florida where Spain was offering freedom and land in an attempt to destabilize the British colonies. They pick up other recruits along the way, burn 6 plantations and kill 23 Whites. The next day they are intercepted by a well armed mounted militia. 47 slaves are killed and the rest are sold off in the markets of the West Indies. The rebellion leads planters to increase restrictions (outlawing literacy, growing food, earning money, and other measures) while explicitly empowering Whites to examine Blacks traveling outside a plantation without papers.", "refs": "[]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1739", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:12Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5083289484263424", "modified": "2018-07-27T20:46:40Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B16"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Treaty of Lancaster. Virginia and Maryland colonies convince the Haudenosaunee Confederacy (aka the \"Six Nations\" or Iroquois) to surrender their land to the \"setting sun\". The Confederacy interprets this as the crest of the Alleghenies and the British colonies interpret it as all of western Virginia. Following King George's War in 1748 between England and France, Virginia pioneers push west of the Alleghenies.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1744", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:12Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5192735183077376", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:12Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N33"},{"tags": "", "text": "Traders begin to use distilled liquor (fire water) to entice agreements. While many Native American Nations/tribes produced mild fermented beverages for ceremonial purposes, they had no distilled liquor and very little time to adapt to what colonists were quite used to. There are no current discovered genetic or other biological anomalies that render Native peoples particularly vulnerable to alcoholism.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1750\u2019s", "qtype": "U", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:13Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5202656289095680", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:13Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N34"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Black slave population in the English Colonies reaches 236,400 with over 206,000 living south of Pennsylvania. Slaves comprise about 20% of the colonies\u2019 population.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1750", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:13Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6262207541149696", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:13Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B18"},{"tags": "", "text": "French and Indian War. The North American theater of the worldwide Seven Years War pits British colonies against French colonies with both sides supported by their parent countries and Native American allies. In the end, France cedes claims to all lands west of the Mississippi to Spain. Overnight, New Spain's territory expands dramatically", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,Latino/as", "date": "1754-1763", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:15Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5139717033033728", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:15Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L7"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Lieutenant-Governor of Massachusetts, seeking to elminate all Penobscot Indians, offers \u00a340 for each male scalp and \u00a320 for each female or child scalp. Rewards for capture are only marginally higher. \u00a340 is over $6,000 today.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1755-11-03", "qtype": "U", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:15Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5151213049872384", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:15Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N39"},{"tags": "", "text": "Filipinos impressed into the Manila Galleon Trade (1565-1815) between Mexico and the Philippines settle in Louisiana after jumping ship", "refs": "", "pic": "6205504040730624", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1763", "qtype": "U", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:17Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6205504040730624", "modified": "2018-04-18T18:20:59Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A1"},{"tags": "", "text": "A pan-Native American confederacy led by Odawa war chief Pontiac (Obwandiyag) launches an attack on the British attempting to take Fort Detroit. He is eventually joined by more than 900 warriors from several tribes. Messengers spread word leading to widespread attacks and eventual control of 9 out of 11 British forts in the region. At General Jeffrey Amherst\u2019s suggestion, Henry Bouquet orders the distribution of smallpox-infected blankets to the Native Americans near Fort Pitt.", "refs": "", "pic": "6258109873913856", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1763", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:16Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6258109873913856", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:16Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N35"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Continental Congress bars Blacks from serving the army during the American Revolution. When the British governor of Virginia offers freedom to all male slaves who join the loyalist forces, General George Washington reverses his position and orders acceptance of free Blacks for military service.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1775", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:19Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6194333636100096", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:19Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B25"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Pennsylvania Society for Promoting the Abolition of Slavery and for the Relief of Free Negroes Unlawfully Held in Bondage (better known as the Pennsylvania Abolition Society) is founded and holds 4 meetings. The society is reorganized in 1784 and sometime after 1785 Benjamin Franklin is elected president. The society requests he bring the matter of slavery to the Constitutional Convention of 1787.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1775-04-14", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:19Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6289557892890624", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:19Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B24"},{"tags": "", "text": "United States Declaration of Independence. The amended form is adopted, which does not include Jefferson\u2019s proposal denouncing slavery. The rationales for separation include a statement that the King is inciting Indian attacks. The revolutionary war had already grown from active resistance in 1773 to open combat in 1775. The war continues until 1783.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American,Latino/as", "date": "1776", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5149586599444480", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:20Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N41"},{"tags": "", "text": "By 1800, the number of Native Americans had been reduced to about 600,000, due to policies of forced displacement and war. The white population of the U.S., however, increased to over 6 million in 1810, and the black population reached approximately one and half million.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American", "date": "1776-1860\u2019s", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5153696748929024", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:20Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N42"},{"tags": "", "text": "The first U.S. treaty with Native Americans (the Lenape - Delaware) recognizing the rights of Native Americans to land they occupy. The Department of State recognizes a total of 375 instruments. The earliest is \"The Great Treaty of 1722 Between the Five Nations, the Mahicans, and the Colonies of New York, Virginia, and Pennsylvania\". The last is in 1869, forcing Chief Joseph and his Nez Perce people off their lands.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1778", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:19Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5196459188158464", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:19Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N40"},{"tags": "", "text": "George Washington orders and organizes the Sullivan Expedition attacking four nations of the Iroquois that had sided with the British. The military campaign destroys more than 40 villages and stores of winter crops forcing Indian families north into Canada. As early as 1753 Washington had been called Conotocaurious (town destroyer) by Seneca leader Tanacharison. By the time Washington is inaugurated president, he is the richest man in the new U.S., based on taking advantage of Indian land deals.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1779", "qtype": "U", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6323770260193280", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:20Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N43"},{"tags": "", "text": "A enslaved woman named Belinda petitions the Massachusetts Legislature for her freedom. The petition is successful and she is granted a pension, one of the earliest recorded examples of reparations for enslavement.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1783", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:21Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6214074379534336", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:21Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B279"},{"tags": "", "text": "Northwest Indian War. Nations/tribes in Ohio led by Miami chief Little Turtle win decisive battles against General Josiah Harmar and General Arthur Saint Clair. Washington then orders General \"Mad\" Anthony Wayne to organize and train a new fighting force that defeats the nations/tribes, forcing them to cede extensive territory, including Chicago, Detroit, Toledo and much of present-day Ohio, in the Treaty of Greenville. The Native Americans receive $20,000 worth of goods and the promise of $9,500 in annuities. Alcohol, hunger, and the threat of military force hasten the Native Americans\u2019 decision.", "refs": "", "pic": "4908329696493568", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1785-1795", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:25Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4908329696493568", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:25Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N45"},{"tags": "", "text": "First U.S. Naturalization Act allows only \u201cfree white persons\u201d to become American citizens.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American,Asian American", "date": "1790", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:22Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4811633608097792", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:22Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N44"},{"tags": "", "text": "First recorded arrival of Asian Indians in the U.S.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1790", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:22Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4879735683284992", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:22Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A2"},{"tags": "", "text": "Congress passes the Fugitive Slave Act, which makes it a criminal offense to harbor a slave, or prevent his or her arrest.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1793", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:26Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4786958752546816", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:26Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B32"},{"tags": "", "text": "Eli Whitney patents the cotton gin, which strengthens slavery by increasing the profits of growing cotton.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1793", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:25Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4882183009337344", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:25Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B31"},{"tags": "", "text": "First major wave of Arab immigration. Motivations include escaping civil war and/or religious persecution. The overwhelming majority are from the Ottoman province of Syria (now Syria, Lebanon, Jordan, and Palestine). Most immigrants are Christian, only 5-10% are Muslim and and an even smaller number are Druze.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Middle East/North Africa,Multiracial", "date": "1800", "qtype": "U", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:27Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5481162906533888", "modified": "2018-07-04T11:21:51Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: M1"},{"tags": "", "text": "By this time 10 to 15 million blacks have been transported as slaves to the Americas, representing perhaps one-third of those originally seized in Africa. It is roughly estimated that Africa lost 50 million human beings to death and slavery at the hands of slave traders and plantation owners in Western Europe and America.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1800", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:27Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6279596655771648", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:27Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B34"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Louisiana Purchase. Having regained ownership of the area in 1800, Napoleon sells the territory to U.S. for $15 million. The territory includes what is now Louisiana west of the Mississippi River (plus New Orleans), Arkansas, Missouri, Iowa, Oklahoma, Kansas, and Nebraska. It also includes parts of Minnesota, North Dakota, South Dakota, New Mexico, Texas, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, and small portions of land within the present Canadian provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan. The U.S. borders now connect directly with New Spain.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,Latino/as", "date": "1803", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:28Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4806699495981056", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:28Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N46"},{"tags": "", "text": "Tecumtha, a Shawnee born in the Ohio region, tries to organize his people, saying,\"The way, and the only way, to check and to stop this evil [of white encroachment], is for all the red men to unite in claiming a common and equal right in the land, as it was at first, and should be yet; for it never was divided, but belongs to all, for the use of each... We must be united; we must smoke the same pipe; we must fight each other's battles; and more than all, we must love the Great Spirit; he is for us; he will destroy our enemies, and make all his red children happy.", "refs": "", "pic": "6034229603336192", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1810", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:31Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6034229603336192", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:31Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N49"},{"tags": "", "text": "Under duress, the Cherokee, Choctaw, Creek, and Chickasaw of the Southeast and the Seminoles of Florida are forced to turn over their lands to Whites and relocate west.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1810", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:29Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6248215343005696", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:29Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N48"},{"tags": "", "text": "Battle of Tippecanoe. William Henry Harrison defeats Native American warriors associated with Shawnee leader Tucumseh at Prophetstown (near the confluence of the Tippecanoe and Wabash Rivers north of Lafayette Indiana). Religious teachings by Tenskwatawa (\"The Prophet\" - Tecumseh's brother) calling for a return to ancestral ways had led to escalating tensions with Harrison and others in the previous years. The year after this battle the U.S. declares war on Britain, its North American colonies, and its Native American allies.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1811", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:31Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6015530121035776", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:31Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N50"},{"tags": "", "text": "First Seminole War. Andrew Jackson begins excursions into West Florida and Spanish Florida against the Seminole (the collective name given to an amalgamation of Native Americans and African Americans who had fled south). This begins the U.S. takeover of Florida and the removal of the Seminole from their land.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1812-1819", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:31Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6008082916179968", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:31Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N51"},{"tags": "", "text": "Creek Native American War (also known as the Red Stick War) due to U.S. cultural and territorial encroachment on native land in Alabama and along the Gulf coast. The war ends with the Treaty of Fort Jackson (August 1814), where General Andrew Jackson insists the Creek confederacy cede more than 21 million acres of land from southern Georgia and central Alabama.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1813-1814", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:32Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5912858659389440", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:32Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N52"},{"tags": "", "text": "Adams\u2013On\u00eds Treaty (aka the Transcontinental Treaty or the Florida Purchase Treaty). Spain sells Florida to the United States for $5 million, paid through settling legal claims of American citizens against Spain. John Quincy Adams is in a strong negotiating position with Luis de On\u00eds as Andrew Jackson already controls two Spanish forts taken in the <a href=\"#N51\">First Seminole War</a>.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1819", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:32Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4872221772218368", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:32Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L149"},{"tags": "", "text": "Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire. New Spain acquires independence from Spain, naming their nation the Republic of Mexico. By this time, Spanish colonies exist in coastal California, southern Arizona, south Texas, and in most of New Mexico and southern Colorado. Soon after Mexico gains independence, Anglo-American settlers begin to move into the Mexican territories of the present day U.S. Southwest, especially Texas.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1821", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:34Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6607062813376512", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:34Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L10"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Denmark Vesey conspiracy in Charleston, South Carolia, one of the most elaborate slave revolts on record, fails. Vesey and 36 collaborators are hanged. In response, slave states adopt laws to further restrict the mobility of Blacks.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1822", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:34Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5487540664532992", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:34Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B45"},{"tags": "", "text": "Mississippi enacts a law prohibiting the teaching of reading and writing to Blacks and meetings of more than 5 slaves or free Blacks.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1823", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:35Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4922856081195008", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:35Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B46"},{"tags": "", "text": "The U.S. Supreme Court upholds the concept of \"right of discovery\", claiming \"discovery gave exclusive title to those who made it\", providing legal justification for the confiscation of Native American lands. In Johnson v. McIntosh, the Supreme Court concludes that tribal sovereignty, although impaired by European colonization, cannot be dismissed.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1823", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:35Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5942455815897088", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:35Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N55"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Bureau of Indian Affairs is created (without authorization from the United States Congress) by Secretary of War John C. Calhoun as a division within his department. Through the late 19th and early 20th century native children are educated in separate assimilation boarding schools prohibiting them from using their indigenous languages, practices, and cultures.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1824-03-11", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:35Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4844988860989440", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:35Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N56"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Trail of Tears. At the request of President Jackson, Congress passes the Indian Removal Act, forcing 92 percent of all Native Americans living east of the Mississippi River to Native American territory west of the Mississippi. The Cherokees, Chickasaws, Yuchis, Creeks, Choctaws, and Alabamas are forced to give up their lands in the southeast. Over 30% of the Cherokees die from disease and exposure in forced migration at gun point as they are moved from their homes in Georgia, the Carolinas, Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee to Native American Territory (Oklahoma); the reservation system begins.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1830-1838", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:36Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6320284894232576", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:36Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N57"},{"tags": "", "text": "Nat Turner leads a slave rebellion in Southampton County, Virginia where rebel slaves kill 55 to 65 people. After a few days the rebellion is put down, the state executes 56 accused slaves, and militias kill another 100. An estimated 200 blacks are killed, most of whom were not involved with the rebellion. The rebellion creates widespread fear. Turner eludes capture for two months but is caught and hanged. His body is then dismembered and the body parts distributed. In the aftermath all dark-skinned inhabitants of Virginia, particularly \u201cfree\u201d people of color (both Indians and Blacks), are terrorized.", "refs": "", "pic": "6269753261817856", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American", "date": "1831-08", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:39Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6269753261817856", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:39Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B51"},{"tags": "", "text": "Second Seminole War (aka the Florida War). The longest and most costly conflict between the United States and Native Americans. The United States ultimately succeeds in forcing the Seminole from their land.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1835-1842", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:40Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4791893401534464", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:40Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N61"},{"tags": "", "text": "Anglo settlers declare the Republic of Texas independent of Mexico. The Texas constitution stipulates that all residents living in Texas at the time of the rebellion will acquire the rights of citizens of the new republic, but if they had been disloyal, these rights are forfeited. Numerically superior Anglos force Mexicans off their property and many cross over the border to Mexico", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1836", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:40Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5924029064019968", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:40Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L12"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Oregon Trail opens. This first interstate highway brings thousands of settlers with cattle and wagons, causing environmental effects that disrupt the buffalo migrations and spread disease.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1842", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:46Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5980732564439040", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:46Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N62"},{"tags": "", "text": "Massachusetts and Vermont state legislatures defy the Fugitive Slave Act and forbid state officials from imprisoning or assisting federal authorities in the recapture of escaped slaves.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1843", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:51Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4840028442198016", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:51Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B56"},{"tags": "", "text": "Mexican-American War. The U.S. invades Mexico under the banner of Manifest Destiny. After tens of thousands dead (including many civilians), the war concludes with the treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo where Mexico cedes what is now Texas, California, most of Arizona and New Mexico, and parts of Colorado, Utah and Nevada. The treaty gives Mexican nationals one year to choose U.S. or Mexican citizenship. 75,000 Hispanic people choose to remain in the U.S. and become citizens by conquest.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1846-1848", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:52Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5976634897203200", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:52Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L14"},{"tags": "", "text": "The California Gold Rush further reduces the Native American population from 150,000 (half the population before white contact) to 30,000.  Native Americans are exploited as mine labor and murdered for racial and economic motives.  Many die from disease or starve to death with the destruction of their food supply by hunting and mining.  Others are driven away.  Before the Gold Rush, Native Americans outnumbered whites by nearly ten to one.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1848-1855", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:51Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4858242056323072", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:51Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N63"},{"tags": "", "text": "California Gold Rush.  Chinese begin to arrive, some as indentured servants. The bulk of these immigrants later become a source of cheap labor for railroads, mines, fisheries, farms, and other industries.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1848-1855", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:52Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4869738073161728", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:52Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A5"},{"tags": "", "text": "Roberts v. the City of Boston. Benjamin Roberts, an African American father sues the city of Boston to allow his five year old daughter to attend a school closer to her home. The lawsuit is part of an organized effort by the African American community to end racially segregated schools. When the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court rules against Sarah Roberts, the ideology of \u201cseparate but equal\u201d is born. The case was defended by Robert Morris who was the first Black lawyer in America to argue a jury case. \nAfter the case lost in the courts, the Black community began to look towards legislature to end segregated public schools. Through the unwavering efforts of the Black community, boycotts, protests and the support of White allies, a law abolishing school segregation is passed in 1855. Boston becomes the first major city in America to open its public schools to African Americans. This successful effort led to other victories such as the opening of theaters and railway cars, the opening of government jobs, a memorial honoring Crispus Attucks and the formation of African American Union regiments to fight in the Civil War.", "refs": "", "pic": "5371311333310464", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1848", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:53Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5371311333310464", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:53Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B58"},{"tags": "", "text": "Buffalo decimation. The two great herds of 15 million buffalo are nearly exterminated by white hunters seeking hides for money.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1849-1885", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:54Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5374583561519104", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:54Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N64"},{"tags": "", "text": "Harriet Tubman escapes from slavery in Maryland. She later returns to the South at least 13 times to help transport approximately 70 enslaved family and friends to freedom. She joins the Union Army as a cook and a nurse, then becomes an armed scout and spy. She is the first woman to lead an armed expedition in the war, and she guides the raid at Combahee Ferry, which liberates more than 700 slaves.", "refs": "", "pic": "5442685636706304", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1849", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:05:55Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5442685636706304", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:05:55Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B59"},{"tags": "", "text": "People vs. Hall forbids Chinese from testifying in court against whites, depriving Chinese of legal protection from violence and freeing Hall who had been convicted for the murder of Chinese miner Ling Sing.  The case is argued as an extension of Section 394 of the Act Concerning Civil Cases, which barred the use of testimony by blacks, mulattoes, and Indians against whites.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1854", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:06:00Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6486979017441280", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:06:00Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A9"},{"tags": "", "text": "Chief Seattle (or Sealth, of the Suquamish) speaks of the interconnectedness of all life:\r\nTeach your children what we have taught our children, that the earth is our mother. Whatever befalls the earth befalls the people of the earth. If you spit upon the ground, you spit upon yourselves. This we know. The earth does not belong to people; people belong to the earth. His teaching becomes one of the most quoted 150 years later, but his land is taken by the Army, which promises to return it when the military establishment to be built there is no longer needed. The land is never returned. It is developed later into private residences.", "refs": "[]", "pic": "6500483468361728", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1854", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:06:01Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6500483468361728", "modified": "2018-08-10T17:44:02Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N67"},{"tags": "", "text": "Dred Scott decision. The Supreme Court rules that \"a negro, whose ancestors were imported into [the U.S.], and sold as slaves\", whether enslaved or free, could not be an American citizen. The court also rules that the federal government has no power to regulate slavery in the federal territories. The decision becomes an indirect catalyst for American Civil War.", "refs": "", "pic": "6037160113209344", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1857-03-06", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:06:04Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6037160113209344", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:06:04Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B62"},{"tags": "", "text": "Chinese are excluded from public schools in San Francisco", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1859", "qtype": "U", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:06:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6047081219227648", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:06:05Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A10"},{"tags": "", "text": "Abolitionist John Brown raids the federal arsenal at Harper\u2019s Ferry, Virginia. Brown\u2019s unsuccessful mission to obtain arms for a slave insurrection stirs and divides the nation. Brown is hanged on December 2.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1859-10-16", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:06:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5965928349040640", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:06:05Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B265"},{"tags": "", "text": "As the Civil War approaches, the U.S. is sharply divided.
