The decision is a victory for NAACP attorney Thurgood Marshall and paves the way for large scale desegregation.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1954-05-17", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:07:59Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6083193304252416", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:07:59Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B141"},{"tags": "", "text": "Two White men are arrested in Greenwood on charges of kidnapping, beating, and shooting 14-year-old Emmett Till. Till, who was from Chicago, was visiting family in Mississippi when he was kidnapped, brutally beaten, shot and dumped in the Tallahatchie River for allegedly whistling at a White woman. The two White men, J.W. Milam and Roy Bryant, are arrested for the murder and acquitted by an all White jury. Jurors acquit the defendants on grounds that the body could not be positively identified. The two men accused of this crime later boast about committing the murder in a Look magazine interview. The case becomes a cause celebre of the civil rights movement.", "refs": "", "pic": "5585870451113984", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1955-08-28", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:01Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5585870451113984", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:01Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B145"},{"tags": "", "text": "Rosa Parks, a NAACP member takes a legal seat in the middle area of a city bus, refuses to surrender it to a White man, and is arrested. In response to her arrest the Montgomery Black community launches a bus boycott, lasting over a year, until the buses are desegregated. Reverend Martin Luther King Jr., the newly elected president of the Montgomery Improvement Association (MIA), is instrumental in leading the boycott.", "refs": "", "pic": "6704400462512128", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1955-12-01", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:00Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6704400462512128", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:00Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B144"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Southern Christian Leadership Conference is formed by Martin Luther King, Jr., Charles K. Steele and Fred Shuttlesworth. King is made the first president. The SCLC becomes a major force in organizing the civil rights movement and bases its principles on nonviolence and civil disobedience. According to King, it is essential that the civil rights movement not sink to the level of the racists and hate mongers who oppose them. \u201cWe must forever conduct our struggle on the high plane of dignity and discipline,\u201d he urges.", "refs": "", "pic": "6134749017931776", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1957", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:03Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6134749017931776", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:03Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B146"},{"tags": "", "text": "Nine Black students in Little Rock, Ark (the Little Rock Nine) are turned away from formerly all-White Central High School by a White mob and the Arkansas National Guard when they arrive for classes. The National Guard, which was called to Little Rock by Governor Orval Faubus, is forced by court order to withdraw on September 20. As mobs of angry Whites assemble outside of the school and the threat of mob violence escalates, President Dwight Eisenhower issues a proclamation on September 23 ordering an end to any obstruction to court-ordered integration. On September 24, the President issues Executive Order No. 10730 authorizing the use of federal troops to assist in the integration of Central High School.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1957-09-04", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:02Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6616546101166080", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:02Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B269"},{"tags": "", "text": "The American Arabic Association is organized in Boston by Francis Maria. AMARA is the first national level Arab American organization, and works to find sponsors for Palestinian children.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Middle East/North Africa", "date": "1959", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6073336891179008", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:05Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: M10"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Cuban Revolution succeeds, Dictator Fulgencio Batista flees Cuba as Fidel Castro takes power, leading to mass emigration to the US.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1959", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6747800301731840", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:05Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L60"},{"tags": "", "text": "U.S. military involvement in Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1960-1975", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:07Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6068451902750720", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:07Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A119"},{"tags": "", "text": "Four Black students from North Carolina Agricultural and Technical College begin a sit-in at a segregated Woolworth's lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina. Although they are refused service, they are allowed to stay at the counter. The event triggers many similar nonviolent protests throughout the South. Six months later, the original four protesters are served lunch at the same Woolworth's counter. Student sit-ins become effective throughout the Deep South in integrating parks, swimming pools, theaters, libraries, and other public facilities.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1960-02-01", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:06Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4935143043104768", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:06Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B147"},{"tags": "", "text": "James Meredith becomes the first Black student to enroll at the University of Mississippi. Violence and riots surrounding the incident cause President Kennedy to send 5,000 federal troops", "refs": "", "pic": "4512162986852352", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1961", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:09Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4512162986852352", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:09Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B152"},{"tags": "", "text": "<a href=\"#B133\">CORE</a> begins sending student volunteers on bus trips to test the implementation of new laws prohibiting segregation in interstate travel facilities. One of the first two groups of \"freedom riders,\" as they are called, encounters its first problem two weeks later, when a mob in Alabama sets the riders' bus on fire. The program continues, and by the end of the summer 1,000 volunteers, Black and White, have participated.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1961", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:09Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4628922209665024", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:09Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B153"},{"tags": "", "text": "C\u00e9sar Chavez leaves the Community Service Organization and co-founds the National Farm Workers Association with Dolores Huerta, a fellow CSO organizer.  Huerta comes up with the slogan \"S\u00ed, se puede\" (\"Yes, it is possible\").  C\u00e9sar's brother Richard and his cousin Manuel come up with the flag design, borrowing the symbol of the eagle from the Aztecs.  They begin organizing, using grassroots, door-to-door, house meeting tactics.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Farm_Workers\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dolores_Huerta\",\"http://www.takepart.com/article/2014/04/02/cultural-history-ufw-flag\"]", "pic": "5149972878065664", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1962", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:14Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5149972878065664", "modified": "2019-03-01T02:25:31Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L65"},{"tags": "", "text": "Mississippi's NAACP field secretary, 37-year-old Medgar Evers, is murdered outside his home in Jackson, Mississipi. Byron De La Beckwith is tried twice in 1964, both trials resulting in hung juries. Thirty years later he is convicted for murdering Evers.", "refs": "", "pic": "5135920818814976", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1963-06-12", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:17Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5135920818814976", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:17Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B155"},{"tags": "", "text": "Martin Luther King is arrested and jailed during anti-segregation protests in Birmingham, Alabama; he writes his seminal \"Letter from Birmingham Jail\" arguing that individuals have the moral duty to disobey unjust laws. \nKing targets Birmingham for a drive against discrimination. The protesters are driven back by police armed with water hoses and attack dogs. The confrontation, which has been captured on film, awakens public opinion across the country.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1963-04-16", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:17Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4575852520013824", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:17Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B157"},{"tags": "", "text": "Four young girls (Denise McNair, Cynthia Wesley, Carole Robertson, and Addie Mae Collins) attending Sunday school in Birmingham, Ala. are killed when a bomb explodes at the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church, a popular location for civil rights meetings. Riots erupt in Birmingham, leading to the deaths of two more Black youths.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1963-09-15", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:16Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4558153765093376", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:16Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B154"},{"tags": "", "text": "Congress authorizes President Johnson to take military action against North Vietnam. From 1964-1975, more than 500,000 U.S. soldiers are sent to Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and Thailand. Two to three million Vietnamese are killed. The first wave of refugees move towards the U.S. through refugee camps.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1964", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:18Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5575909213995008", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:18Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A121"},{"tags": "", "text": "Three young civil rights volunteers, James Chaney, Michael Schwerner, and Andrew Goodman, are murdered in Neshoba County, Mississippi. A number of arrests follow. Among the 19 suspects are the sheriff and a deputy sheriff of Neshoba County. The state refuses to prosecute. Federal civil rights violation charges are brought against the suspects in 1967, after years of effort by federal prosecutors blocked by prejudicial legal manipulations, an all-White federal jury finds seven men guilty, acquits 9, and deadlocks on 3. The seven begin serving sentences between 3-10 years. Among the guilty are Chief Deputy Sheriff Cecil Price and Sam Bowers, Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan. In 2005, Edgar Ray Killen is convicted on three counts of manslaughter.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1964-06-21", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6061042949947392", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:20Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B163"},{"tags": "", "text": "Malcolm X leaves the Black Muslim organization, Nation of Islam, to form the Organization of Afro-American Unity (OAAU) \u2013 an organization emphasizing Black nationalism and social action.", "refs": "", "pic": "5510386937757696", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1964-06-28", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:19Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5510386937757696", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:19Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B161"},{"tags": "", "text": "President Johnson signs the Civil Rights Act. The most sweeping civil rights legislation since Reconstruction, the Civil Rights Act prohibits discrimination of all kinds based on race, color, religion, or national origin. The law also provides the federal government with the powers to enforce desegregation.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American,Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa", "date": "1964-07-02", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:17Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5618671653224448", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:17Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B158"},{"tags": "", "text": "President Lyndon Johnson announces the arrest of four Ku Klux Klan members in connection with the murder of Viola Gregg Liuzzo. Liuzzo, a 39-year-old White civil rights worker from Detroit, was slain at Lowndes County highway during the Selma-to-Montgomery Freedom March. The president declares war on the Klan, calling it a \u201chooded society of bigots.\u201d Robert M. Shelton Jr., Imperial Wizard of the United Klans of America, Inc., answers the President\u2019s charges by branding him \u201ca damn liar.\u201d On March 30th, the House Un-American Activities Committee votes to open a full investigation of the activities of the Klan. The Committee chairman, a Louisiana Democrat, asserts that the Klan is committing \u201cshocking crimes.\u201d", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:21Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5544527901229056", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:21Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B167"},{"tags": "", "text": "Although minor reforms in immigration law, due to changing international relations, allowed for limited numbers of Asians to enter the U.S. following the World War II era, U.S. immigration laws remained discriminatory toward Asians until 1965 when in response to the civil rights movement, non-restrictive annual quotas of 20,000 immigrants per country were established. For the first time in U.S. history, large numbers of Asians were able to come to the U.S. as families. \u201cFamily\u201d is based on strictly heterosexual and nuclear ties. Law explicitly defines lesbians and gay as \u201csexual deviates.\u201d", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1965", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:23Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5671618936307712", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:23Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A123"},{"tags": "", "text": "Blacks begin a march to Montgomery in support of voting rights but are stopped at the Pettus Bridge by a police blockade. Fifty marchers are hospitalized after police use tear gas, whips, and clubs against them. The incident is dubbed \"Bloody Sunday\" by the media. The march is considered the catalyst for pushing through the voting rights act five months later.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-03-07", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:21Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5548676302766080", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:21Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B166"},{"tags": "", "text": "The arrest and alleged mistreatment of a Black youth by White policemen sparks looting, burning, and rioting in the predominantly Black section of Watts. Thousands of National Guardsmen and state police are rushed in to quell the violence. The rioting, which lasts six days, claims the lives of thirty-five people and causes nearly 46 million dollars in property damage. On August 20, President Johnson denounces the Los Angeles rioters, comparing them to Ku Klux Klan extremists. He declares that the existence of legitimate grievances in Watts is no justification for lawlessness. \u201cWe cannot...in one breath demand laws to protect the rights of all our citizens, and then turn our back...and...allow laws to be broken that protect the safety of our citizens.\u201d", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-08-11", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:21Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5582611107807232", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:21Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B168"},{"tags": "", "text": "The mostly Filipino American members of the AFL-CIO affiliated Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee, walk out on strike against Delano-area grape growers. They ask Chavez's largely Latino NFWA to join the walkouts. On September 16, Mexican Independence Day, the NFWA, with 1,200 member families, votes to join the walkout, beginning the five-year Delano Grape Strike. Latino and Filipino strikers work together, sharing picketlines, strike kitchens and a union hall. Chavez asks strikers to take a solemn vow to remain nonviolent.", "refs": "[\"https://ufw.org/1965-1970-delano-grape-strike-boycott/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"https://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/eclipsed-cesar-chavez-larry-itliongs-story-now-emerges-n423336\",\"https://www.sfchronicle.com/opinion/article/50-years-after-the-Delano-grape-strike-6508846.php\"]", "pic": "5638062893694976", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as,Asian American", "date": "1965-09-08", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:23Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5638062893694976", "modified": "2019-03-22T19:27:51Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L70"},{"tags": "", "text": "Asserting that civil rights laws alone are not enough to remedy discrimination, President Johnson issues Executive Order 11246, which enforces affirmative action for the first time. It requires government contractors to \"take affirmative action\" toward prospective minority employees in all aspects of hiring and employment.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-09-24", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:21Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5505501949329408", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:21Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B169"},{"tags": "", "text": "More than 250,000 Cubans are airlifted to the U.S. Congress passes the Cuban American Adjustment Act allowing Cubans who lived in America for at least one year to become permanent residents.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1966", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:25Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4605449676521472", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:25Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L73"},{"tags": "", "text": "Race riots in Detroit, Newark, Chicago, Cleveland and other urban centers leave many dead, thousands injured, and miles of destruction. Underlying causes are discrimination in housing, education, training, jobs, police abuse, and other acts of white racism.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1966-1970", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:26Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6752443429814272", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:26Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B172"},{"tags": "", "text": "The militant Black Panthers are founded by Huey Newton and Bobby Seale. [pic: Bobby Seale]", "refs": "", "pic": "6754178059730944", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1966", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:25Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6754178059730944", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:25Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B171"},{"tags": "", "text": "Hundreds of Puerto Rican youths riot in Chicago after police shoot a Puerto Rican man at the the first Puerto Rican parade in the city. Rioting begins at Division Street and grows, continuing for days, fueled by a long history of discrimination and slow progress of civil rights.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1966-06-12", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:25Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5498092996526080", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:25Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L72"},{"tags": "", "text": "In Los Angeles, Latino high school students organize city-wide walkouts. Previously, Latino students were not allowed to use the bathroom during lunch, were discouraged from applying to college, and were punished for speaking Spanish on school property. Police respond with brutality: 13 students are arrested. The walkouts impact school reform and increase college enrollment by Latinos.", "refs": "[]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1968", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:31Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5635094534422528", "modified": "2018-08-10T17:31:09Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L75"},{"tags": "", "text": "The world is shocked by the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. The assassination moves the United States House of Representatives to submit to President Johnson a Senate-passed civil rights bill prohibiting racial discrimination in the sale or rental of 80 percent of the nation\u2019s housing. Johnson signs the measure on April 11, while the King assasination riots are still sweeping the United States. James Earl Ray, alleged assassin of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. is arrested June 8 in London, England.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1968-04-04", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:29Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5701752426856448", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:29Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B176"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Indian Civil Rights Act revises Public Law 280 by requiring states to obtain tribal consent prior to extending any legal jurisdiction over a Native American reservation.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1968-04-11", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:30Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6744571560067072", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:30Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N120"},{"tags": "", "text": "Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. is awarded the Nobel Prize for Peace.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1964-12-10", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:19Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5628278152888320", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:19Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B162"},{"tags": "", "text": "Riots erupt in the Harlem section of New York City. One person is killed, 140 injured, and 500 arrested. This is considered the first of many large riots that are to strike urban Black neighborhoods during the sixties. Shortly after the Harlem disturbances, riots erupt in Brooklyn, New York; Rochester, New York; Jersey City, New Jersey; and Paterson, New Jersey.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1964-08-18", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6646143257673728", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:20Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B164"},{"tags": "", "text": "The U.S. Supreme Court, which ruled against Jim Crow laws in the 1954 decision of Brown v. Board of Education, rules as invalid a Florida statute allowing harsher penalties for cohabitation and adultery by interracial couples than same-race couples in McLaughlin v. Florida. This case is said to be a predecessor to the Loving v. Virginia case (in 1967).", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Multiracial", "date": "1964-12-07", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:18Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5571799064510464", "modified": "2018-07-04T11:34:17Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: R90"},{"tags": "", "text": "Malcolm X, a 39-year-old Black nationalist leader and former member of the Black Muslim sect, is shot to death in the Audubon Ballroom in Manhattan as he is about to deliver an address before a rally of several hundred followers. Following the murder, Black Muslim headquarters in New York and San Francisco are burned, and most Muslim leaders are placed under heavy police guard.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1965-02-21", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:22Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5616597452455936", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:22Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B170"},{"tags": "", "text": "The US invasion of Santo Domingo during the Dominican Civil War marks the beginning of a massive migration to the US.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1965-04-30", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:22Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5206676378484736", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:22Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L69"},{"tags": "", "text": "Congress passes the Voting Rights Act, making it easier for Southern Blacks to vote. Literacy tests, poll taxes, and other such requirements that were used to restrict Black voting are made illegal. In addition, jurisdictions containing significant language minority populations are required to provide bilingual ballots and other election materials.", "refs": "[]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American,Latino/as,Asian American", "date": "1965-08-06", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5626543522971648", "modified": "2019-01-11T01:31:57Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B165"},{"tags": "", "text": "President Johnson\u2019s National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders (aka the Kerner Commission) reports on the causes of the civil disorders that disrupted the nation in 1967, identifying the major cause of the rioting as the existence of two separate bodies in America, \u201cone Black, one White, separate and unequal.\u201d It charges that White racism was the chief catalyst that ignited so many urban ghettos in 1967: \u201cWhite institutions created it, White institutions maintain it, and White society condones it.\u201d To overcome this terrible and crushing legacy, the commission implores the nation to initiate a massive and sustained commitment to action and reform, and appeals for unprecedented levels of \u201cfunding and performance\u201d in housing, education, employment, welfare, law enforcement, and the mass media.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1968-02-29", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:31Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4520571190640640", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:31Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B179"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Civil Rights Act (aka the Fair Housing Act) provides sweeping housing, voting, education and other protections and enforcement capabilies together with anti-riot measures.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American,Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa,Multiracial", "date": "1968-04-11", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:30Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6697698971353088", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:30Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B177"},{"tags": "", "text": "Senator Robert Kennedy, a champion of civil rights, is shot and killed moments after leaving a rally celebrating his victory over Eugene McCarthy in the California Democratic primary.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American,Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa,Multiracial", "date": "1968-06-06", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:32Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4505676780929024", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:32Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B180"},{"tags": "", "text": "Black Panther Huey P. Newton is tried and convicted of manslaughter in the October 28, 1967 shooting death of a White policeman. Nearly three weeks later, Newton is sentenced to 2-15 years imprisonment. The trial and the conviction introduce the nation at large to a new and formidable Black Panthers.", "refs": "", "pic": "6701809120837632", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1968-09", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:30Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6701809120837632", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:30Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B178"},{"tags": "", "text": "Four hundred treaties protecting Native Americans have been broken by this year. The newly formed American Indian Movement (AIM), organized in midwestern cities by Dennis Banks, Clyde Bellecourt, and others, represents a militant voice for Native American rights. One program, modeled after the Black Panthers, monitors police. [pic: Dennis Banks]", "refs": "", "pic": "4507240685895680", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1969", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:33Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4507240685895680", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:33Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N122"},{"tags": "", "text": "Puerto Rican youth in Chicago form the Young Lords Organization. Modeled after the Black Panthers, and an outgrowth from the Young Lords street gang, the organization uses direct action and education to focus public attention on Latino issues such as slums, poor schools, and unemployment. The YLO becomes an active community organization providing multiple services including free breakfast for children and health clinics. Later the YLO spreads to New York City.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1969", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:34Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6742497359298560", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:34Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L77"},{"tags": "", "text": "The U.S. secretly invades Cambodia as a strategy to destroy Viet Cong hideouts and supports. Over the next four years, literally tons of U.S. bombs are dropped on Cambodian villages and cities along the South Vietnam-Cambodia border, killing and injuring civilians with no formal declaration of war against Cambodia.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1969-03-18", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:34Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4590708275019776", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:34Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A200"},{"tags": "", "text": "Members of Native Americans of All Nations/tribes occupy Alcatraz Island in San Francisco, claiming the right under an 1868 Sioux Treaty stating unused federal land would revert to Native Americans. The Native Americans stay on the island until June 1971. The Alcatraz occupation brought together hundreds of Native American people who came to live together on the island and thousands more who identified with the call for self-determination, autonomy, and respect for Native American Culture.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1969", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:32Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5731349583364096", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:32Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N121"},{"tags": "Thanksgiving", "text": "Plymouth Mass officials invite a Wampanoag man, Frank James, to speak at Thanksgiving festivities, requesting he provide his speech in advance. The officials disapprove of James' historically accurate account of contact between colonialists and Native Americans, so they provide their own speech for him to read instead. Frank James refuses to read their speech and instead begins the National Day of Mourning, a yearly observance at Plymouth, MA commemorating the social and political struggles of native people.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Day_of_Mourning_(United_States_protest)\",\"http://uaine.org/suppressed_speech.htm\"]", "pic": "5643365970345984", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1970", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:36Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5643365970345984", "modified": "2018-11-19T17:12:28Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N124"},{"tags": "", "text": "Title II of the <a href=\"#A114\">McCarran Internal Security Act of 1950</a>, which would have legalized detention camps, is repealed.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1971", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:38Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6269637029265408", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:38Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A125"},{"tags": "", "text": "President Nixon signs into law the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act, granting Alaska's 60,000 Native Americans, Inuits, and Aleuts title to 44 million acres of their ancient homeland and $962.5 million in settlement of the <a href=\"#N76\">century-old question of Native land rights</a>.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1971", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:38Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6328478618091520", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:38Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N128"},{"tags": "", "text": "Chavez begins a 24 day fast at the Santa Rita Hall in Phoenix, after Arizona Governor Jack Williams signs a new law essentially banning the right of farm workers to strike, boycott, or organize.  Chavez helps to replace Jack Williams with Ra\u00fal H\u00e9ctor Castro in 1974.", "refs": "[\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Chavez\",\"https://www.nytimes.com/1972/05/21/archives/chavez-continues-a-fast-in-arizona-protests-farm-labor-law-mcgovern.html\",\"http://chavez.cde.ca.gov/ResearchCenter/DocumentDisplayRC.aspx?rpg=/chdocuments/documentdisplay.jsp&doc=6bec47%3Aea792358ca%3A-7ac7&searchhit=yes\",\"http://barriozona.com/cesar-e-chavez-in-phoenix-1972-fast-at-the-santa-rita-hall/\",\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1974_Arizona_gubernatorial_election\"]", "pic": "5691423567380480", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1972-05-12", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:41Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5691423567380480", "modified": "2019-03-20T18:18:56Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L79"},{"tags": "", "text": "Many people from the Pine Ridge Reservation and supporters, led by <a href=\"#N122\">AIM</a>, occupy Wounded Knee to bring attention to corrupt and unjust treatment by tribal, state and federal governments. Wounded Knee is again ringed by high-tech weaponry, this time in the hands of the combined forces of local and federal agencies. Several die, several are wounded, the violence on Lakota lands intensifies.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1973", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:46Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6230432567787520", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:46Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N130"},{"tags": "", "text": "The right of Puerto Rican people to decide their own future as a nation is approved by the United Nations. In 1978, the United Nations recognizes Puerto Rico as a colony of the United States.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1973", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:46Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6234568889729024", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:46Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L83"},{"tags": "", "text": "A government panel releases its final report determining whether the Tuskegee Syphilis Study, conducted between 1932 and 1972 by the Public Health Service, was justified. The study involved observing the effects of untreated syphilis of 430 Black men living in rural Macon County, Alabama. The panel found no evidence that participants in the study had been given any type of informed consent. The panel concluded that the study was unjustified on both scientific and humanitarian grounds and that all policies regarding research on humans be reformed.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1973-04-24", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:45Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4551452273934336", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:45Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B184"},{"tags": "", "text": "Santos Rodriguez and his brother David (12 and 13 years old) are pulled from their home by police, handcuffed, placed in a police car, and accused of stealing $8 from a gas station vending machine. One of the officers plays Russian roulette with Santos who insists he is telling the truth about not being involved. The officer shoots Santos and kills him. The Mexican-American community organizes a peaceful protest, but it turns violent with damage to police property, injuries and arrests. The need for change is recognized by the city. Over the next 40 years Dallas increases the percentage of non-white police officers and creates a citizen's police review board.", "refs": "", "pic": "5138802473435136", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1973-07-24", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:44Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5138802473435136", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:44Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L81"},{"tags": "", "text": "Violence erupts between supporters and opponents of public school integration. Boston busing reaches national attention, and white flight to the suburbs accelerates.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1974", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:47Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4862262145712128", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:47Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B185"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Department of Justice releases memos revealing that in the 1960\u2019s and early 1970\u2019s, the Federal Bureau of Investigation had waged a campaign designed to disrupt, discredit, and neutralize Black nationalist groups, including the Black Panther Party. A major objective of the effort, according to the memo, was to prevent the emergence of a Black leader capable of uniting disparate factions and inspiring violence. Reverend Jesse Jackson remarks that the documents implicate the FBI in the deaths of the Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Malcolm X, and Fred Hampton. [pic: Fred Hampton]", "refs": "", "pic": "4868497901355008", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1974", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:48Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4868497901355008", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:48Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B186"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Equal Educational Opportunity Act makes bilingual education available to Hispanic youth. According to the framers of the act, equal education means more than equal facilities and equal access to teachers. Students who have trouble with the English language must be given programs to help them learn English.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1974-08-21", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:48Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4878730124066816", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:48Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L84"},{"tags": "", "text": "South Vietnam surrenders to the Communist forces of the North. The U.S. evacuates Vietnam, leaving approximately 30,000 American children behind. The U.S. lacks policies to deal with the Amerasians fathered by U.S. servicemen, and demonstrates no intention of recognizing the children, in stark contrast to the French response in 1954 after the first Indochina war. France allowed repatriation of all Eurasians (~25,000), providing repatriation travel, educational opportunities, and citizenship at age 18.  Amerasian children endure severe trauma and persecution in Asian home countries.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American,Multiracial", "date": "1975-04-30", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:49Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4882002352275456", "modified": "2018-05-22T20:58:07Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A127"},{"tags": "", "text": "The fall of Vietnam and Cambodia begins large-scale immigration of Vietnamese, Laotian, and Cambodian refugees to the U.S. More than 130,000 refugees enter the U.S. Boats are frequently attacked by pirates, who loot, beat and rape the refugees. Most refugees spend years in refugee camps and transit centers prior to arriving in the U.S.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1975-04-30", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:49Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6251926194749440", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:49Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A128"},{"tags": "", "text": "Shootout between <a href=\"#N122\">AIM</a> members and FBI agents on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota. Two FBI agents enter the Pine Ridge Reservation claiming they are looking for a tribal member on theft and assault charges. Shots are fired under confusing circumstances, resulting in the death of two FBI agents and one AIM member. AIM activist Leonard Peltier is arrested, tried, and convicted for the deaths of the FBI agents, despite numerous continuing concerns as to the fairness of the proceedings.", "refs": "", "pic": "5128473613959168", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1975-06-26", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:50Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5128473613959168", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:50Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N133"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Supreme Court, in Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education, upholds busing as a legitimate means for achieving integration of public schools. Although largely unwelcome (and sometimes violently opposed) in local school districts, court-ordered busing plans in cities such as Charlotte, Boston, and Denver continue until the late 1990s.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1971-04-20", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:37Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5108668982886400", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:37Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B181"},{"tags": "", "text": "<a href=\"#A91\">Executive order 9066</a> (signed in 1942) is officially rescinded.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1976", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:51Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5645059932291072", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:51Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A129"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation files suit against neighboring landowners to recover land illegally sold to them by the State of Connecticut in 1855. After 7 years, they reach a settlement with the landowners who agree the land was sold illegally and join the Pequot in seeking state government support. The Connecticut legislature petitions the federal government to grant tribal recognition and settle the claim. In 1983, the Mashantucket Pequot Indian Land Claims Settlement Act appropriates funds enabling the land to be repurchased and placed in trust.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1976-05", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:51Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6264702380277760", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:51Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N134"},{"tags": "", "text": "Hearing the case University of California v. Bakke, the United States Supreme Court, in a 5 to 4 decision, orders that White student Allan P. Bakke be admitted to the medical school at the University of California, Davis. The Court rules that the refusal to admit Bakke is tantamount to reverse discrimination and that the use of racial or ethnic quotas is an improper means of achieving racial balance. The Court also holds that the college\u2019s affirmative action program is invalid, since it had the effect of discriminating against qualified White applicants, although the Court perceived the goal of attaining a diverse student body constitutional and permissible.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1978-06-28", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:54Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4595593263448064", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:54Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B188"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Japanese American Citizens League (<a href=\"#A81\">JACL</a>), at its Salt Lake City convention, adopts a resolution calling for redress and reparations for the internment of Japanese Americans.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1978-07-22", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:55Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6004630030909440", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:55Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A130"},{"tags": "", "text": "Political upheaval and civil wars in Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala contribute to large migrations of refugees to the United States.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1979", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:56Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5919880394047488", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:56Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L88"},{"tags": "", "text": "U.S. military intervention in El Salvador, Guatemala, Nicaragua, Grenada, Lebanon, Libya, Iran, and Panama", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1980-1989", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:00Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5431447854776320", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:00Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L92"},{"tags": "", "text": "Programs to apprehend undocumented immigrants are implemented, and reports of violations of civil rights are reported.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1980s", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:00Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5444952305696768", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:00Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L93"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Black Liberty City area and predominantly Black Coconut Grove section of Miami erupt into riotous violence, ending with 9 dead and 163 injured, following the acquittal of four White Dade County police officers in the beating death of a Black man.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1980", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:59Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6282368922943488", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:59Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B189"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Refugee Act of 1980 removes the definition of refugee as one who flees from a Communist regime, allowing thousands of others to enter the United States as refugees. The act provides comprehensive and uniform provisions for the effective resettlement and absorption of refugees, with up to 50,000 refugees admitted each fiscal year and emergency procedures for when that number exceeds 50,000.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa", "date": "1980-03-17", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:57Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5082109978869760", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:08:57Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L89"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Maine Indian Claims Settlement Act allocates $81.5 million for the benefit of the Passamaquoddy and Penobscot, in part allowing them to purchase lands in Maine, and extinguishing all aboriginal title in Maine. The act settles the <a href=\"#N131\">land claim</a>, leading to recovery of more than 300,000 acres and a $27 million trust fund.", "refs": "[]", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American", "date": "1980-12-12", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:08:58Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5114402227355648", "modified": "2018-09-12T16:15:11Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: N138"},{"tags": "", "text": "Maya Lin\u2019s design for the Vietnam Veteran\u2019s Memorial is selected out of 1,441 competition submissions. Designs were identified only by number, and after Lin's design (number 1026) wins, objections are voiced based on Lin being Asian (she is the daughter of Chinese immigrants), female, and lacking professional experience. At the time, she was a 21-year-old student at Yale. The memorial becomes a pilgrimage site with people leaving items, a practice that started with a purple heart thrown into the foundation concrete during construction in 1982. The monument receives around 3 million visitors each year.", "refs": "", "pic": "6208009885712384", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1981-05", "qtype": "F", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:03Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6208009885712384", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:03Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A140"},{"tags": "", "text": "More than 250 churches provide \u201csanctuary\u201d to Salvadoran and Guatemalan refugees", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1982", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:04Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6240302134198272", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:04Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L94"},{"tags": "", "text": "Vincent Chin, a 27-year-old Chinese American in Detroit, is bludgeoned to death by 2 unemployed autoworkers who blame layoffs on the Japanese and mistake Chin as Japanese. The 2 men, Robert Ebens and his stepson Michael Nitz, are sentenced to 3 years probation and fined $3000. The case becomes a rallying point for the Asian American community which overcomes inaction from traditional civil rights groups to eventually bring federal civil rights charges. In 1984, Nitz is acquitted and Ebens is sentenced to 25 years. Ebens sentence is overturned on appeal in 1986. In 1987 he is cleared of all charges. A civil suit is then settled out of court for $1.5 million, but without garnishment it is never paid off.", "refs": "", "pic": "5118512376840192", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1982-06-19", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5118512376840192", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:05Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A137"},{"tags": "", "text": "Congress expands Section 2 of the <a href=\"#B165\">Voting Rights Act</a> to explicitly ban any voting practice that has a discriminatory effect, irrespective of whether the practice is enacted or operated for a discriminatory purpose.  No longer does the legal process have to prove that the intent of the local law was to discriminate, it needs only to demonstrate that it could have a discriminatory result.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1982-06-29", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6209421050904576", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:05Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B196"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Amerasian Homecoming Act offers top-priority U.S. immigration to children in Korea, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, or Thailand who are known to have been fathered by U.S. citizens. The act does not grant admission to mothers or other relatives.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American,Multiracial", "date": "1982-10-22", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4874994039390208", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:05Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A138"},{"tags": "", "text": "Susie Guillory Phipps unsuccessfully sues the Louisiana Bureau of Vital Records to change her racial classification from Black to White. Phipps was designated as \"Black\" in her birth certificate in accordance with a 1970 state law which declared anyone with at least one-thirty-second \"Negro blood\" to be Black. The court upheld a state law which quantified racial identity, and in so doing affirmed the legality of assigning individuals to specific racial groupings. The appeal reached the U.S. Supreme Court in 1986 but was \u201cdismissed for want of a substantial federal question\u201d.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Multiracial", "date": "1983", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:07Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5759782535299072", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:07Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: R96"},{"tags": "", "text": "Americans adopt more that 33,000 infants from the People\u2019s Republic of China.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1985-2002", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:09Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5688164224073728", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:09Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A143"},{"tags": "", "text": "Alex Odeh, regional director of the <a href=\"#M19\">American-Arab Anti Discrimination Committee</a> on the West Coast, is killed by a bomb triggered to explode when he opens his office door in Santa Ana, California. Previously on August 16, two police were injured dismantling a bomb at the ADC office in Boston and another bomb was discovered near the home of an Arab-American physician in Cambridge, Massachusetts. On November 29, a two-alarm \"suspicious\" fire at the ADC headquarters in Washington DC burns out of control for 45 minutes gutting the ADC offices. No arrests are made.", "refs": "", "pic": "4517085824679936", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Middle East/North Africa", "date": "1985-10-11", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:14Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4517085824679936", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:14Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: M22"},{"tags": "", "text": "In Wygant v. Jackson Board of Education the U.S. Supreme Court (in the first of three major affirmative action decisions) rules 5 to 4 that broad affirmative action plans including hiring goals are permissible if carefully tailored to remedy past discrimination. In a ruling involving teachers laid off in Jackson, Michigan, the court sends a mixed signal by deciding that public employers cannot give affirmative action plans as a substitute for seniority when reducing their work forces.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1986-05-19", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:15Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4910397186375680", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:15Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B195"},{"tags": "", "text": "The United States Supreme Court upholds the use of affirmative action plans designed to remedy past discrimination ruling on actions regarding Cleveland printers and New York sheet-metal workers. In Sheet Metal Workers International v. EEOC, the court rejects the Reagan administration\u2019s argument that only specific victims of discrimination are entitled to such relief.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1986-07-02", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:15Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6201012847116288", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:15Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B194"},{"tags": "", "text": "A federal grand jury in Fort Smith, Arkansas indicts 15 White supremacists. Among the charges are conspiring to assassinate federal officials, including a judge, and killing members of ethnic groups through bombings. In Denver, another federal grand jury indicts 4 other White supremacists in connection with the murder of radio talk show host Alan Berg.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American,Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa,Multiracial", "date": "1987-04-21", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:17Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5484053687959552", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:17Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B198"},{"tags": "", "text": "A federal indictment in Raleigh, North Carolina charges 5 members of white supremacist groups with conspiracy to acquire stolen military weapons, explosives and equipment.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American,Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa,Multiracial", "date": "1987-01-08", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:16Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5960453607915520", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:16Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B197"},{"tags": "", "text": "Navroze Mody, a South Asian Indian man living in Jersey City, is beaten to death by a group of youths allegedly affiliated with the \u201cDotbusters\u201d, a hate group whose name refers to Bindi worn by traditional Hindu women and girls. Attacks and harassment continue until 1993.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1987-09-27", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:17Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6551112005976064", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:17Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A146"},{"tags": "", "text": "With tens of thousands of Amerasians still in Vietnam living with discrimination and persecution throughout their childhoods, the Amerasian Homecoming Act improves the <a href=\"#A138\">1982 Act</a> to allow Amerasians born between 1962 and 1977 to immigrate together with family members. The children are classified as immigrants, but granted refugee benefits including 6 months of language and culture orientation.  Initially a 2-year plan, it was extended twice due to slow processing.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1988", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5420277450145792", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:20Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A149"},{"tags": "", "text": "Overriding President Reagan\u2019s veto, Congress passes the Civil Rights Restoration Act, which expands the reach of non-discrimination laws within private institutions receiving federal funds.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1988-03-22", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:21Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4800635002159104", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:21Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B199"},{"tags": "", "text": "The U.S. Senate votes 69-27 to support redress for Japanese Americans, creating the Civil Liberties Act of 1988. President Reagan signs the Act giving each surviving internee a tax-free compensatory payment of $20,000 and a letter of apology. At the time there are approximately 60,000 surviving persons.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1988-08-10", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:20Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5972898544091136", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:20Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A148"},{"tags": "", "text": "U.S. reaches agreement with Vietnam to allow political prisoners to emigrate to the U.S.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1989", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:24Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4790669604290560", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:24Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A150"},{"tags": "", "text": "The United States Supreme Court toughens the requirements for proof of discriminatory impact in job discrimination suits. The Court also declares that in such cases, an employer might justify policies which have a discriminatory impact by providing a reasonable business explanation. In a second case, the Supreme Court rules by a 5 to 4 majority that White workers claiming unfair treatment due to affirmative action settlements can seek compensation under civil rights legislation.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1989", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:24Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6000893946232832", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:24Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B200"},{"tags": "", "text": "Patrick Purdy fires 105 rounds from an assault rifle at children in an elementary schoolyard in Stockton California, killing five Southeast Asian children and wounding 30 others before killing himself with a pistol.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "1989-01-17", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:24Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5158543216869376", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:24Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A151"},{"tags": "", "text": "FBI Director William Sessions orders sweeping changes in the Bureau\u2019s affirmative action program after finding that the bureau had discriminated against minority employees. Ironically, the FBI is the agency charged with enforcing the nation\u2019s civil rights laws.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1989-02-28", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:25Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6294299536785408", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:25Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B201"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Quality Education for Minorities Project releases its report and recommendations aimed at making schools more responsive to the needs of minority students. The project concludes that minority students are taught in \u201cseparate but decidedly unequal\u201d schools resulting in a \u201cgap between minority and non-minority educational achievements.\u201d", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1990-01", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:29Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6051101308616704", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:29Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B202"},{"tags": "", "text": "The Immigration Act thoroughly revamps the <a href=\"#L67\">Immigration and Nationality Act</a> making allocation of visas more even among foreign nations, eliminating archaic rules, and increasing the level of worldwide immigration. This act welcomes skilled workers but limits their stay to 6 years. The act removes homosexuality as a reason to disqualify foreigners from immigrating, or even visiting, the U.S.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa", "date": "1990", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:28Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6204285880631296", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:28Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A153"},{"tags": "", "text": "Black motorist Rodney King is severely beaten by several White police officers after being stopped for a speeding violation.", "refs": "", "pic": "6196090546159616", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1991", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:33Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6196090546159616", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:33Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B207"},{"tags": "", "text": "After two years of debates, vetoes, and threatened vetoes, President Bush reverses himself and signs the Civil Rights Act, strengthening existing civil rights laws and providing for damages in cases of intentional employment discrimination.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American,Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa,Multiracial", "date": "1991-11-21", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:31Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5916569511133184", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:31Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B204"},{"tags": "", "text": "Riots erupt in Los Angeles following the acquittal of four White police officers in the beating of Black motorist Rodney King. Korean businesses are looted and burned.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American,Asian American", "date": "1992", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:35Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5488151355195392", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:35Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B209"},{"tags": "", "text": "The North American Free Trade Agreement is signed by U.S. President George H. W. Bush, Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and Mexican President Carlos Salinas. The agreement is ratified by each country over the next year. NAFTA expands even further the maquiladora concept, offering potentially greater tax abatements for U.S. businesses. A maquilladora is a manufacturing operation where a factory imports raw material and equipment on a tariff-free and duty-free basis, then exports the product, sometimes back to the country of origin.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1992-12-17", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:34Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6251114177495040", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:34Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L105"},{"tags": "", "text": "A joint resolution is passed by Congress to acknowledge the 100th anniversary of the overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii and to formally apologize to the Native Hawaiians for depriving them of their rights.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,Asian American", "date": "1993-11-23", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:41Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4741264863920128", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:41Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A156"},{"tags": "", "text": "The U.S. government implements a blockade strategy along the U.S. Mexico border, forcing migrants to cross through the desert: Operation Gatekeeper (CA), Operation Safeguard (AZ), and Operation Blockade/Hold The Line (TX). Over the next decade, over 3,000 people die while trying to cross the border.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1993-10-01", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:40Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4737992635711488", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:40Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L108"},{"tags": "", "text": "California Governor Pete Wilson issues an executive order for state officials to begin following Proposition 187 by cutting off services to undocumented pregnant women and nursing home patients.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1994-11-09", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:41Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5402578695225344", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:41Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L109"},{"tags": "", "text": "Californians pass Proposition 187 with 59% of the vote. The initiative bans undocumented immigrants from receiving public education and public benefits such as welfare and subsidized health care, except in emergency circumstances; makes it a felony to manufacture, distribute, sell or use false citizenship or residence documents; and requires teachers, doctors and other city, county, and state officials to report suspected and apparent illegal aliens to the California attorney general and the INS.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1994-11-08", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:41Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5407501264617472", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:41Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L112"},{"tags": "", "text": "Federal District Court Judge William Mathew Byrne Jr. issues a temporary injunction against the state of California forbidding enforcement of Proposition 187, stating that it raises serious constitutional issues. He exempts the provisions that increase penalties for manufacturing or using false immigration documents.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1994-11-11", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:44Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5926534909001728", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:44Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L111"},{"tags": "", "text": "The University of California votes to eliminate affirmative action policies in the admission of students.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1995-07-21", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:46Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4787151757639680", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:46Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B218"},{"tags": "", "text": "Proposition 209, introduced as a ballot initiative, is passed by the California voters. The initiative bars preferential treatment based on race or gender, virtually eliminating affirmative action in state hiring, public contracts, and education. Although challenged in the court, the U.S. Supreme Court refused to hear the appeal, and Proposition 209 eventually takes effect in California.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American,Latino/as", "date": "1995-11-05", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:46Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6012824560074752", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:46Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B220"},{"tags": "", "text": "Federal Judge Mariana Pfaelzer rules that <a href=\"#L112\">Proposition 187</a> is unconstitutional.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as", "date": "1997-11-14", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:49Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6205935684943872", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:49Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: L114"},{"tags": "", "text": "President Bush signs into law the Hate Crime Statistics Act, requiring the Justice Department to maintain statistics on acts of violence directed against members of racial, ethnic, and religious groups. This act was passed due to the efforts of a broad coalition of groups including the ADC, the American Psychological Association, the National Council of Churches, and the American Jewish Congress. At the ADC\u2019s initiative, mosques were added to the list of institutions covered by the Hate Crimes Act.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Native American,African American,Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa,Multiracial", "date": "1998-04-23", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:52Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5386007637655552", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:52Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B272"},{"tags": "", "text": "James Byrd Jr., 49, a Black salesman, is dragged to death by 3 racists in Jasper, Texas; his body is dismembered.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "African American", "date": "1998-06-07", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:09:55Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "6041257512009728", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:09:55Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: B222"},{"tags": "", "text": "The first year that people can identity as more than one race on Census. 2.4% of the U.S. population endorses more than one race.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Multiracial", "date": "2000", "qtype": "D", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:10:00Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5351665616027648", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:10:00Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: R106"},{"tags": "", "text": "An elderly Lao man, Thung Phetakoune, is murdered by a White man who called him Vietnamese and blamed him for the Vietnam war.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Asian American", "date": "2001", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:10:10Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5779142905692160", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:10:10Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: A167"},{"tags": "", "text": "The extremist terrorist group Al-Qaeda attacks the U.S. using hijacked airplanes. The first hijacked airplane flew into the North Tower of the World Trade Center, the second hijacked plane flew into the South Tower of the World Trade Center, the third hijacked plane flew into the Pentagon, and the last hijacked plane crashed into the ground near Shanksville, Pennsylvania.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Middle East/North Africa", "date": "2001-09-11", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:10:08Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5863892542554112", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:10:08Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: M40"},{"tags": "", "text": "Start of attacks against persons who only appear, at least to some Americans, to be Middle Eastern, Arab, or Muslim. People who \u201cappear\u201d Muslim have also been attacked even though Muslims are found among all races, ethnic groups, and nationalities. In the context of U.S. hate-violence, however, \u201cMuslim\u201d has been equated with Middle Eastern or Arab. Sikh men who wear turbans have also been lumped with \u201cArab\u201d terrorists and victimized. In short, a confluence of events in U.S. history leads to the construction of a new racial stereotype and target for bias, fear, and hate crimes: persons who are or appear to be \u201cMiddle Eastern, Arab or Muslim.\u201d", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Middle East/North Africa", "date": "2001-09-15", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:10:01Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "4798560801390592", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:10:01Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: M30"},{"tags": "", "text": "Balbir Singh Sodhi, a Sikh, is shot in Mesa, Arizona at the gas station he owned. ", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Middle East/North Africa", "date": "2001-09-15", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:10:07Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5847424564199424", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:10:07Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: M38"},{"tags": "", "text": "Immigration and Naturalization services changes the regulation regarding detentions. An alien can be detained without charge for 48 hours or \u201can additional reasonable period of time\u201d if there is an \u201cemergency or other extraordinary circumstance.\u201d Many people draw a parallel between the internment of over 110,000 Japanese Americans after the Pearl Harbor attack with the detention and deportation of MENA people after 9/11.", "refs": "", "pic": "", "orgid": "5757715179634688", "groups": "Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa", "date": "2001-09-17", "qtype": "", "categories": "", "created": "2018-04-18T17:10:05Z;5652786310021120", "instid": "5910363820261376", "modified": "2018-04-18T17:10:05Z;5652786310021120", "regions": "", "source": "ksep: M31"},{"tags": "", "text": "According to the organization South Asian American Leaders of Tomorrow (SAALT), 645 bias incidents were reported in metropolitan newspapers across the country in the week after 9/11.
